BREAK.PARA: These amendments propose to introduce a uniform retail tenancy code utilising the Commonwealth's corporations power under section 51(xx) of the Australian constitution.

Despite comments that were made by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) in the House yesterday, in answer to a dorothy dix question, we are not proposing under any circumstances to introduce any taxing powers, and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Cadman) should know better as well. The way our amendment has been drafted specifically precludes that particular issue. It was one part of the advice the MTAA received and they suggested that that might be one way for this to be put in place. We clearly ruled that out and it is not part of this proposal.

In respect of this uniform retail tenancy code, we have looked at a number of those codes and we have also drawn on the recommendations of the fair trading inquiry report. In the amendment I have moved, under division 2—Uniform retail tenancy code—that is a direct lift of recommendation 2.2 of the Reid committee report. Minimum term of retail shop and service station leases is recommendation 2.4; lease renewals is also recommendation 2.4; lease assignment is recommendation 2.5; standard set of lease provisions is recommendation 2.9; precontract disclosure is recommendations 2.5 and 2.7; market rent review is recommendations 2.6 and 2.7; disturbance to trading is recommendation 2.11; retail tenancy mix is recommendation 2.10; merchants associations to be consulted is recommendation 2.8; statements of outgoings is recommendation 2.8; and dispute resolution provisions is recommendation 2.3.

Under enforcement, retail lease tribunals to be established is recommendation 2.3; application of retail lease tribunal is recommendation 2.3; consideration of matters by retail lease tribunal is recommendation 2.3; and action where recourse to Retail Lease Tribunal has not resolved dispute is recommendation 2.3.

I read through that because it does illustrate a point we made earlier in this debate; that is, the recommendations that the opposition is moving to strengthen the provisions of the Retail Act that we are dealing with tonight are direct lifts from the Finding a balance: towards fair trading in Australia report brought down under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), with the support of the honourable member for Cowan, both of whom voted against that during the course of tonight's discussions.

The recommendations in section 2 on retail tenancy have been completely skirted by the government; not one piece of legislation has come forward from the government in respect of this. The government is claiming that constitutionally this is not possible. We vehemently disagree that this is not possible and we believe that a uniform retail tenancy code developed at the national level gets over many of the problems of inconsistencies at the state level. It is going to be there and we have said that it is a proposal which, in our view and in the view of the committee that reported—but we have seen tonight already that quite a number of those committee members have walked away from the recommendations that they signed up to before—will certainly help small business.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Cadman), who is at the table, is shaking his head. Think back to that meeting in Newcastle. Most of the people there were retail tenants. There are stories of misery contained in the fair trading inquiry report about retailers having to battle major shopping centre owners and operators to get a fair deal, a fair go that the government keeps talking about. We believe that is possible through the amendments that we are proposing tonight.

Quite obviously, we find it extraordinary that the government cannot see that this is a possibility. Again, why is it that the Reid committee made recommendations about retail tenancy issues, about putting retail lease tribunals in place, giving good cheap access to justice, and now they are walking away from all of them? It is a real question that needs to be asked. I am sure those on the other side who served on this committee will probably be looking at themselves in the mirror tonight or tomorrow and asking themselves the same question. If they do not, when they get back to their constituencies I am sure the small business community will, by the time we get through telling them all about what you have voted on. This report, as I have said, we adopt in full. The government were supposed to do that and they have squibbed it. I would like to know why they squibbed this most important element of the committee report. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I must first respond to the comments the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) made early this evening and I would point out to him just a couple of little things. The first thing is that I did not spend hours berating the member for Flinders (Mr Reith) about what he had done in the last 13 years; he did that to us. I think his record in that context does not stand scrutiny. Secondly, the member for Paterson failed to mention the fact that I was actually a member of the Beddall committee. I actually went to most of the hearings then, too, as on this one. He also failed to admit, accept or concede publicly that he attended one hearing, simply because it was a meeting in Canberra. He did not come to any of the hearings around Australia; he took very little evidence; he signed up to the report and is now walking away from it. The fact is that he has been asked by business people in Newcastle to cross the floor on this issue. He has chosen not to, and he should explain that to his community and to his business people because they expected better of him.

SPEECH.PARA: The first dot point in the terms of reference in this inquiry states:
the major business conduct issues arising out of commercial dealings between firms including, but not limited to, franchising and retail tenancy.

Retail tenancy is up there in lights as part of this inquiry. It is without doubt the most difficult area in small business trading around the country and it was also the subject of the majority of submissions. As a local member, as I am sure my colleagues on both sides of the parliament are, I am getting constant concerns coming forward from people who are in difficulty in retail tenancies. A lot of our time was spent on this aspect of the report; we put a lot of effort into trying to work through what we should do. We ended up with a set of recommendations for a national tenancy code.

The fact is that, if we cannot do this, why were we given the reference? Is the government so incompetent that it gave us a reference about retail tenancies, knowing that we could not legislate? Are we so badly advised by our secretariat and all those who made submissions to us that we spent an awful lot of our time and a lot of public resources on retail tenancies, with a recommendation for a national code enshrined within the Trade Practices Act, only to be told by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) that we cannot do that? What is going on here? We have suddenly got a concocted report from a lawyer who says—and I gather the minister is saying this—we can do this only if it is about taxes. So he is somehow trying to run this line that the committee recommendation was for a new tax.

What these amendments are about is adopting the recommendations of the committee for a national tenancy code enshrined within the Trade Practices Act. That is what it is about. It is simple; it is not a complex concept. It is legal, it is constitutional and it is desirable. For too long we have had competing states with confusing and conflicting legislation.

I will just touch on one small issue: the rights of existing tenants, which is probably the single most important issue in shopping centres. We recommended that sitting tenants have rights, a right to renewal—not the right to leave, which is what the landlords say. What they were saying to the committee was that, once the lease runs out, that is it. So people plan their lives for three or five years and somehow they are supposed to recover all their costs and investments in that short time. This has never been the case before because there was always a thing called goodwill. The landlords now say there is no goodwill, simply a lease; and when it is finished, you have to assume you are going to go. We said no, we should assume there is a right to renew—a logical, natural, moral position.

The South Australian parliament is legislating now to in fact enshrine such a right. Nowhere else in Australia is. So what we are suggesting is that we do not want this state versus state, bit by bit practice; we want a uniform single code, not simply in theory but backed up by the Trade Practices Act. If we cannot do it, why the reference? If we cannot do it, why did the chairman of the committee and the government majority have us spend all this time on it and why on earth did we recommend it? It just does not make any sense. Either the government is stupid or it is wrong now. I support the amendments. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting these amendments, I think we have to place on record that the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology did indeed believe that the Commonwealth had powers to underpin a uniform retail tenancy code in the Trade Practices Act 1974. If we go to recommendation 2.2 on page 26, and I will read it for completeness, we see that it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Minister request the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to approve the Uniform Retail Tenancy Code for underpinning in the Trade Practices Act 1974 , thus providing for the courts to take into account provisions of the Uniform Retail Tenancy Code in determining whether or not business conduct in the area of retail tenancy has been `unfair' and thus unlawful.

I acknowledge that the context of that recommendation is slightly different from the proposal that has been put forward tonight. But we have to remember that, in the response to the committee's report, the weakest part of the government's response was in the area of retail tenancy matters. The committee made the important recommendation that these issues be taken to the ministerial council. Paragraph 2.41 at page 27 states:
The Committee does not see such underpinning as a substitute for quick, low cost resolution of individual disputes through State and Territory retail tenancy dispute resolution processes.
We acknowledge that state and territory jurisdictions have a lot to do in this. Even this amendment, clause 131, `Saving of other laws and remedies', states:
This Part is not intended to exclude or limit the concurrent operation of any law in force in a State or Territory.

The simple matter is that in the government's response to the fair trading report the federal government's position is left up in the air as to what should be contained in a uniform retail tenancy code. This is an attempt to ensure that the matters that were highlighted by the committee are included in a uniform retail tenancy code. The amendment covers most of those matters that were highlighted by the committee. So that is the issue that we see tonight in the consideration of these amendments.

Firstly, there is the furphy that this cannot be done. There is the furphy that it can only be done and it involves some form of taxing powers, which is just one of those throwaway lines to camouflage what is not a proper debate of the issues at hand. The other thing is that, regrettably, after all the work that was done by the committee and all the matters that were highlighted by the committee, the government's response was mute about the federal government's position on all the matters that were outlined. That is a disappointment, because the issues that were put to us by retail tenants were harrowing, and they continue to occur. As I mentioned in my second reading contribution to this bill, they continue to occur, whether it be through changes of retail tenancy mix or whether it be through changes to disturbance of trading because of redevelopment and the like.

These matters are real. They affect small businesses from one end of Australia to the other. Consistent in what the committee was exposed to was that, no matter where we went, the stories were similar, the stories were very distressing and the effect that it had had on the people that were involved in these small businesses was real. This is an attempt by the opposition to put this uniform retail tenancy code forward so that it can give direction to where the federal government sees these matters going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the final contribution tonight, regrettably, because of the time constraint that has been placed on us, I will just quickly reiterate what the purpose of these two amendments is. Firstly, Labor is attempting to introduce the uniform retail tenancy code utilising the Commonwealth's corporations power under section 51(xx) of the Australia constitution. Secondly, in relation to lease renewal or extension, the uniform retail tenancy code would require an independent market review jointly financed by both the leaser and the lessee. The code would include a pre-contract disclosure statement in line with recommendation 2.5 of the Reid report. Disclosures would include disturbance to trading, retail tenancy mix, consultation with merchant associations and a statement of outgoings. The code would be prospective and only apply to small businesses, not to anchor tenants. The code would provide for a step‐by‐step dispute resolution mechanism and also cover service stations.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the reasons we are doing this are that we maintain the Reid committee report did set some standards. We believe the Commonwealth has the power to do this. We believe it is important for retail tenants to understand that they are going to get some protection; they are going to know that when they are entering into lease arrangements with shopping centre owners those arrangements are going to be done in an atmosphere of fairness and equity. At the present time in many cases that is not the case.

We also believe that each of those proposals we have put forward here directly lifts from the Reid committee report and, therefore, I reiterate that we cannot understand why those members of the government that sat on this committee now have walked away from this and have let the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) simply abrogate any responsibility in respect of the matter. The reason I say this is that I know he is meeting with small business ministers from the states on Friday. I know that at that meeting he is going to put to them some heavies, as he has done to many small business organisations, saying, `Cop what we're putting up or you'll get nothing at all.'

I find that extraordinary when, in the light of evidence that was given to the Senate estimates committee on 12 November this year, a representative of the Office of Small Business indicated that there was absolutely no chance of their getting a uniform agreement on uniform retail tenancy laws across the states, that there has not been in the past and there will not be in the future. That is why a uniform retail tenancy code is necessary from the national level—a top‐down approach—and we are providing that opportunity again. Labor, as usual, is providing that opportunity.

Finally, the minister and many others on the other side have talked about `political smokescreens'. They have claimed that this is a stunt, and all the rest of it. I again say to those opposite that this is not a stunt. Labor is genuinely trying to ensure that the fair trading legislation we are dealing with gives small business a fair go. Labor is attempting to keep honest those recommendations which came from the fair trading inquiry report, which had the unanimous support of those committee members.

Labor has adopted that report. We cannot for the life of us understand why the government has decided not to do so—a government which constantly berates Labor for what it is purported not to have done in its term in office, a government which says that it is, after all, the high priest looking after the interests of small business. I think small business will be the judge of this. When they find out that members of the committee and the government itself have chosen not to support the recommendations which they have been looking for in the small business community they will be stunned. I commend our amendments to the House. I regret that we do not have longer to debate each and every one of them in the fine detail that I would like, but we certainly will do when the Senate considers these matters next year.

PARA.TAB: That the amendments (Mr Martin's ) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In this adjournment debate, I would like to talk about the work of United Way, an organisation which raises finances through voluntary payroll deductions to assist a number of charities in particular regions. Currently, there are nine separate United Way groups operating in Australia. I became interested in this organisation when, as president of the Labor Council of New South Wales, the then secretary, Michael Easson, invited me to take his place on the board of United Way in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: The organisation distributes finances collected to over 20 charities on a twice‐yearly basis in the Sydney metropolitan area. The charities that receive assistance for specific projects range from: community outreach ministries, which give practical help in housing and the teaching of living skills to homeless youth and young people suffering from mental disabilities; the Riding for the Disabled Association, which provides therapeutic and recreational horse riding and related activities, including harness driving and vaulting, to people with disabilities; the Children's Leukemia and Cancer Foundation, which provides quality care and support for affected children and families as well as world‐class research to find cures and more effective treatments; the Infants Home at Ashfield, which provides early intervention programs for children aged six weeks to five years and their families—and the intervention programs include child abuse, crisis accommodation for mothers and children and a day stay program for issues relating to children under two years. These are just four worthy charities that are assisted. To give this parliament an idea of what United Way is about, I quote from a message from the chairman, Robert Sutton:

I invite you to join the United Way team and urge you to support this wonderful concept of `sharing and caring' in United Way's campaign to raise funds for a broad range of health and welfare agencies that operate in the Sydney region.

The driving force of our organisation is volunteer effort and the success of fundraising campaigns have demonstrated how effective and worthwhile the United Way volunteer approach is in helping the less fortunate among us.

United Way operates on a large scale in many countries and I have been involved with the organisation in the United States and in Asia, seeing first hand the important contribution it can make through having employers and employees working together in a co‐operative and voluntary fashion towards the common goal of contributing to support local community needs.

In Sydney we have made an important start with the support of a number of major organisations, and the many thousands of dollars distributed over the last five years to local human care groups is already making a difference. I am confident that United Way is destined to become one of the most important sources of funds to health and welfare agencies in the region.

United Way of Sydney operates on the basis that, by March each year, charities are asked to submit applications for funding projects which focus on services in response to crises or a change in the circumstances for families, children or the aged, or a combination of these.

Highest priority will be given to applications that are from an approved beneficiary; are for the funding of a project, not the entire organisation; have a budget which clearly shows United Way funds supplementing other funds already being applied to the project; show that funding has a direct impact on the clients of the project; and are for a period of 12 months. Applications are then considered by a beneficiaries committee, which undertakes a formal review of each application and accompanying documentation that shows proof of compliance with United Way requirements.

There are many calls on the generosity of our community due to the many problems facing our society—whether we are looking at drugs, homelessness, escalating crime, concerns for our safety, poverty and worries about the care of our children and the elderly, just to name a few.

There are many national organisations such as the Smith Family, the Salvation Army and St Vincent de Paul, who are all staffed by volunteers, and many smaller organisations, such as the Tuesday night club in my electorate of Greenway, which assists intellectually handicapped people. All of these organisations are deserving of our generous support. However, United Way seeks to top up charities that have already proved their worth to society but are still in need of additional equipment. People who agree to contribute a small amount each week through payroll deduction, as far as United Way Sydney is concerned, are assisting 20 charities. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Every year I run the Fisher electorate essay competition in two sections—a primary school section and a secondary school section. Over the last couple of days I have been privileged to host the winners in Canberra and would like to congratulate the winning primary student, Cohen Devereux, of Matthew Flinders Anglican College, Buderim, and Tracey Barnes, from Yarraman P-10 School, who won the secondary section. Both of these students reside in my electorate. The topic this year is `How Australia, the best country in the world, can be made even better'. I would like to read the winning essays into Hansard . The essay by Cohen Devereux reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Sandy beaches famous attractions such as the Sydney Opera House, Ayers Rock and many theme parks. These are just a few of the things that make Australia the best country in the world. With Australia being the sixth largest country in the world I think we have to set a good example to other smaller countries. I think the three main things we need to focus on are crime, tourism and pollution to certainly make Australia the best country in the world. These subjects will appear in the order that I have stated them in.
CRIME

Crime is a subject that I think we as a nation really need to crack down on. Did you know that four out of every 100,000 people are murdered in Australia. The situation is further complicated because more and more tourists are coming to Australia all the time which means that there is more people in Australia resulting in more murders. This shows why tourists are afraid to come to Australia because of these facts. Capital punishment should be returned to the penalty list for people who commit serious crimes. If this is done then eventually crime will be minimal and tourists won't be afraid to visit our wonderful country every now and then.
TOURISM

Tourism is a big money earner to Australia so I think that Australia should invest a little more money into tourist's attractions and accommodation. If this is done there will be less unemployment because of new facilities being opened therefore leaving many vacancies in job positions. When these facilities are opened people from far and wide will hear about the wonderful activities and accommodation in Australia and will come to see for themselves.
POLLUTION

Pollution is the bad side of our wonderful country. It destroys the country's natural physique and ruins its beauty. Another bad thing about pollution is that tourists hate it and return to their own countries with bad health reports. With the government investing money into the big businesses that cause the pollution and not investing much money into stopping pollution it makes bringing in more money for other things like tourism very hard.

To conclude I would like to say that Australia is a beautiful place and the three things we need to focus on to make it even better are crime, tourism and pollution. So just keep these subjects in mind and maybe even carry them out and we can make our nation BETTER!
The essay by Tracey Barnes reads:
You hear about people complaining about our country's faults but they never come up with any real solutions that everyone agrees on.
To make Australia a better country than it already is, we've got to stop and think about where we want to be in the future.
I understand that some people won't like my suggestions, but this is what I, myself believe, will make us a greater country than we already are.

I think employment levels can be improved upon by not buying overseas products. Instead we could produce them here in Australia. That way we would not only create more jobs, but we would be saving money by not having to pay the fee for overseas imports.

If this doesn't work and people are still on the dole, they can always work for their money, such as helping their local council, even if it is only once a week. That way, they'll not only feel better by doing something, but they will also have something written in their resume for when they do go for a job interview.
Our health system could be improved upon by having more people immunized. I know that a small percentage of people are allergic to these, but isn't it a risk worth taking?

Hundreds of crimes are being committed each year throughout Australia. To lessen this number harsher penalties are needed. This could include longer sentences and less luxurious prison cells. (This would cost less because money wouldn't be spent on comfort.) Even the death penalty could be reintroduced for cold hearted crimes such as murder and rape.

Already over half of our forests have been destroyed over the past two hundred years. Where we will be in another two centuries if we keep on this way? We need timber to build houses, furniture and to make paper, just to name a few, but we also need forests for our wildlife, picnics and for future generations to enjoy. Recycling is a great idea, the more we recycle the less trees that have to be cut down. Another idea is to plant trees where forests once existed. This would need to be done each time a tree is cut down to be effective.
I'm sure if all Australians worked together we could bring these suggestions into reality. That way, even though we are already the best country in the world, we would be even better.

I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate these students and to thank the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) for their courtesy in meeting these students. I would also like to thank the Chief Government Whip (Mr Andrew) for his courtesy to them. I know you, Mr Speaker, were keen to see them but your commitments meant that this was not able to occur. These are outstanding young people. We have every reason to be proud of them and I hope to see two more wonderful young students from Fisher in parliament next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hanson, Pauline, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It saddens me to speak of the stolen children, but with the current division produced by the ridiculous notion that native title has validity it is a subject that must be raised. I speak of course of the thousands who, from the turn of the century until the 1960s, were taken from their parents and forced to travel great distances where they found themselves living in the company of strangers. Evidence shows that some suffered sadistic treatment and sexual abuse—horrors that can never be excused. Many of the records have been destroyed and very few of these innocent children were ever reunited with their relatives. Indeed, it was a dark period in our young nation's past.

SPEECH.PARA: It may surprise the House to know that I do not speak of Aboriginal children but of the estimated 40,000 children transported to Australia by various British charities. The story of the stolen British children parallels that of the stolen Aboriginal children. It all happened around the same time and many of the reasons for separation from families were similar. The justification will always be a source of argument and, of course, in both cases there were reports of terrible ill-treatment. In perspective, there were approximately 150,000 stolen British children. Not only did those sent to Australia apparently outnumber their Aboriginal counterparts but it seems that, with very few exceptions, they did not return home or experience any family reunion.

You could argue at length the differences between what was suffered by each group and the rights and wrongs of separation, but that serves no purpose. The point is that the stolen British children sent to Australia and indeed the removal of children from the slums of Melbourne in the early part of the century put more into context the equality of suffering. I do not wish to attempt to justify what happened to the Aboriginal people. Rather, the point is that they do not have a monopoly on suffering, and history clearly shows that to be the truth.

When Noel Pearson was reported recently as declaring war on white Australia, all Australians should have realised the war started long ago when Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal activists began their unconscionable public relations exercise aimed at raising the level of guilt in white Australia. In this PR war, truth was the first casualty, for truth would not serve the purpose of the strategic attack on the emotions and conscience of ordinary Australians.

The young in particular have fallen foul of this outrageously deceitful exercise aimed at bringing us to the point where we are about to give perhaps as much as 80 per cent of our country to about two per cent of our popula tion—all in the name of compensation and to free ourselves of the guilt so carefully cultivated and effectively massaged into our minds.

There is no doubt many Aborigines are disadvantaged, but there equally is no doubt they are not on their own in their suffering either now or in the past. There are plenty of examples of, as I said before, equality of suffering, but this PR machine of guilt assaults us with indecent comment not balanced by the surrounding circumstances of history. The stolen children report, Bringing them home, was just one of the more recent examples designed to make us guilty about the past. It was sad. It was terrible and individual stories tugged at the hearts of Australians everywhere—myself included. But it was as if these awful privations were solely owned and experienced by Aborigines. Of course, that is a lie.

If the report's purpose was guilt, it served well and its timing was impeccable. We cannot turn back the hands of time, and no amount of compensation will ever change what happened. We will never have true reconciliation until we rid our society of divisive policies clearly based on race alone. We must also rid ourselves of those who financially feed off the exercise of misleading both the Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people of Australia. Equality for all Australians is the only path to a cohesive future as one nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to welcome the recent announcement by the United States oil giant Texaco of its intention to pull out of operations in Burma. I too share the view displayed by the company's shareholders and the free‐thinking Burmese people that this decision is a victory for democracy. The human rights abuses which the SLORC has perpetuated against the nation of 45 million people is well documented. It has been raised in the House by numerous other speakers. I am pleased the message from Aung San Suu Kyi and the National League for Democracy is being received by the governments of democratic nations and, more importantly, by multinational corporations whose operations prop up and preserve the power of the SLORC and its generals in Burma.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to quote the Reverend Paarlberg, a leader of the Reformed Church of America, an organisation that has been very vocal in its opposition to companies which have a history of doing business with companies which display a poor record in the area of basic human rights. He said:
Texaco's decision is a tremendous victory for the Burmese people. It sends a clear message to Burma's military dictatorship that there will be no Business As Usual, until democracy returns.

We know that multinational oil company investment provides the largest legal source of currency to the regime. We also know that this particular industry relies heavily in its early developmental stages on a substantial labour force. It is this recruitment of labour and the methods used by the SLORC which have led Amnesty International to report that what particularly distinguished the Burmese junta from other modern tyrannies was its use of slave labour.

We should remind investors in oil companies which participate in these projects that the money derived from such ventures, constructed on the bones of Burmese men, women, and children, cannot be justified as contributing to the wealth of the country. I hope the decision taken by Texaco will increase the pressure on other companies to seriously consider their continued operations in Burma. It has been reported that there is a growing protest in some states of America against companies doing business with the SLORC. Businesses have been urged to restrict trade with the military junta.

While Texaco's decision has been welcomed by the wider community, the decision by Premier Oil of Britain to buy Texaco shares in the Yetagun project still does not resolve the issue of foreign investment. A spokesperson for the National Coalition Government of the Union of Burma said:
We welcome Texaco's gesture and we appeal to Premier to seriously reconsider their deal with Burma's illegitimate regime.
We believe it is against the current trend of the UK Government's Burma policy and the position of Aung San Suu Kyi who advocates no foreign investment with SLORC.

The United Kingdom government is following the line adopted by the United States. The United Kingdom foreign minister said that his government would discourage economic activity in Burma and would urge companies considering doing business in that country to think about their human rights record and listen to the government's advice before making a decision about whether or not to proceed.

In July, the Burton Group and Polo Ralph Lauren became the latest groups to pull out of Burma. The Burton Group issued a statement that it had instructed its suppliers to place no further contracts for sourcing from Burma and to terminate all existing contracts by the end of the year. In its statement the company said that it is the Burton Group's policy to listen to its customers and this decision has been taken following a review of customer opinion.

We in the House acknowledge the firm stand taken by the United States President, Bill Clinton, and leaders of some European countries. However, we should also welcome the initiative taken by our Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon. Mr Alexander Downer, to further investigate the impact of investment in Burma by Australian companies.

A representative of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr John Dauth, was recently sent to Rangoon as a special envoy in an effort to seek practical ways to bring about democracy and a greater respect for human rights in the country. Mr Dauth passed on the message to Burma's foreign minister that Australia was looking to them to make tangible progress towards democratic institutions and the better observance of human rights. He also urged the SLORC to seriously consider dialogue with the National League for Democracy and its leaders. I note from an article in this week's national media that already the SLORC has opened up a crack in the wall and invited communication with the NLD—a move which has been welcomed by many nations.

BREAK.PARA: The visit allowed Mr Dauth to raise the Australian government's concerns about the human rights situation in Burma directly with the key players. It is important to note that throughout this process Australia has remained in touch with Aung San Suu Kyi and will continue to consult with her about our Burma policy. I applaud the minister for taking this initiative and his efforts to keep open the channels of communication.

It is vital that we in Australia continue our support for the people of Burma in their fight to restore democracy to the country. I hope Australian businesses will take a good look at the human rights record of the country before committing their resources.
Finally, let me quote a journalist from the Canberra Times who is well acquainted with the country. He said:

Any initiative to try to force change in Burma is welcome. However we should not forget the grim realities of Burma. We should not overlook the thousands of innocent men, women and children who suffer and die at the hands of military thugs each year or those dying from disease in the border camps. And we should not forget those who legitimise the peddlers of this misery also have blood on their hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on a very important principle of international environmental law in its application to the development at Port Hinchinbrook. This principle is a precautionary principle and it is concerned specifi cally with the risk to the environment brought about by human activity. It operates so that, where the probability of the occurrence of the event and its likely consequences are uncertain, measures taken to avert the possibilities involved with such events are necessarily precautionary. It is a principle which has received increasing acceptance at international levels since its conception in the 1970s and it was recognised as `a statement of commonsense' in a 1993 decision of the New South Wales Land and Environment Court.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my opinion that this principle should be applied to the activities that are being carried out at Port Hinchinbrook. It should be applied in order to effect an immediate cessation of the development, pending an assessment of the environmental degradation that has occurred at that site. This call comes as a response to what appear to be repeated and flagrant breaches of the deed of agreement pursuant to which the development of Port Hinchinbrook was to go ahead, breaches that local residents have claimed include unapproved acid sulfate soil excavation, failure to treat acid sulfate soil, discharge of acids and excavated materials into the sea and into the melaleuca forests, muddy run‐off causing plumes stretching three kilometres over seagrass beds, creation and operation of dredge spoil ponds without proper standards of engineering or approval, dredging of the marina basin without an appropriate licence, and the wholesale and unapproved destruction of mangroves. Nor was there a Commonwealth approved environmental management plan, acid sulfate management plan or turbidity control plan in place, or an independent monitor appointed before the site works were begun.

The development at Port Hinchinbrook is now larger than the development consented to by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill). What started with a restricted resort including a marina basin now incorporates a harbour and an artificial beach stretching for one kilometre, resplendent with coconut palms. A third excavation site is currently under way. These additions have commenced without approval.

BREAK.PARA: However, it is perhaps the dredge spoil ponds containing excavated acid sulfate soils and discharge which are the main source of concern. The walls of the dredge spoil ponds on the southern site were crudely constructed, and the ponds themselves were built across a natural freshwater catchment. The ponds are filled with a sulfuric acid solution, despite the fact that this catchment feeds a melaleuca forest. In addition, pipes exist across and through the walls, draining the build‐up of water that threatens to collapse the walls into the adjacent melaleuca forest. This melaleuca forest is classified `unallocated state land' which has been environmentally designated as the critical habitat of the endangered mahogany glider and an ecosystem of concern.

The developer at Port Hinchinbrook relies on dilution and on the buffering capacity of seawater to raise the pH level to neutral. However, buffering changes the chemistry in ways that are harmful to marine life, and allows the metals and organics content of the sulfuric acid to precipitate out onto the fine clay particles which are then borne to the Great Barrier Reef, from where the metals enter the food chain. Breaches for this month are staggering: the destruction of mangroves; the dumping and spreading of sand on the foreshore at Oyster Point, effectively suffocating the mangrove replanting area; repeated long‐term turbidity plumes arising from the development, streaming off Oyster Point on the outgoing tide and being carried over world heritage beds; and dredging right through world heritage seagrasses.

There has been no comprehensive assessment of Port Hinchinbrook and its environmental impacts. I am yet to see or hear of a report suggesting that the development should go ahead. I have, however, received a plethora of material which more than suggests that this development should be stopped immediately.

It is incumbent on this generation to err on the side of caution when it comes to developments such as that at Port Hinchinbrook. This is because environmental impacts do not respect borders. The development at Port Hinchinbrook is destroying the environmental status quo on the edge of a world heritage area. While we are witnessing the devastating effects the development is currently having on the environment, no‐one can speak with certainty of the long‐term and potentially irreversible effects of this continuing development. Let us place the onus on the developer to show why, in light of all the contradictory evidence, his development should go ahead. But let us do it now, before it is far too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford, Rod, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training report entitled Youth employment: a working solution . I also take the opportunity to congratulate the committee Chairman, the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), committee members and the secretariat—in particular, James Rees, Paul McMahon and Gaye Milner.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally speaking, the committee reached agreement in a bipartisan way on the first four chapters, but that was simply not possible in chapter 5, on youth wages, where opposition members could not agree in any way with the recommendations made by the government members, and one member of the committee, the member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel), wrote a minority report. This was because, in essence, the government members, whether they realised it or not, recommended that Australia go down the income inequality direction so prevalent in the United States.

I recently read an article where the mayor of Chicago was reported as saying that his city was in the midst of an employment boom—$6 an hour, and you could get a job anywhere. If that is a boom, God help us all. A couple of years ago, I was in Denver and, in the mall, a very polite young man came up to me and asked me for the price of a hamburger and a cup of coffee. Just on the corner, there was a sign that said: Work available. I said, `Why don't you go and get a job?' He took me around to where there was a stall selling all sorts of things, and it was $2.70 an hour. In that sort of context, of course, employment becomes a bit of a joke.

Youth employment opportunities bedevil the developed world, and Australia is no exception. Governments that fail to lead in the employment debate for young people will be judged harshly by history. In recent weeks, Channel 9 and News Limited promoted a commendable jobs for Australia campaign, securing promises from employers for 20,000 jobs. However, the stark reality is that those 20,000 jobs, if they eventuate, would do nothing, absolutely nothing of a fundamental nature, to change the chronic and endemic unemployment that stagnates the economies of Australia and the developed world. For me, that campaign reinforced the fact that the jobs are simply not there, not only for younger but, indeed, for older workers.

This inquiry focused on young people aged from 15 to 24 years of age. In this brief speech to the Main Committee I wish to address three points which, for me, are the substance of the report. The first refers to the age group five to 15. This is the age where children gain literacy, numeracy and the often forgotten social and technological skills. Although there are privileged and vested interest in the education sector denying that there is a crisis in our primary and junior secondary schools, there is no escaping the fact that when Australia is compared to other OECD countries we are nearly at the bottom when it comes to expenditure on the age group of five to 15. There are severe consequences for this failure.

There are unacceptable literacy rates. Arguments about whether it is 33 per cent, 25 per cent or even 20 per cent are irrelevant. When you look at the figures over the last 20 years, probably the aggregate data has not changed much. But what has changed is that the top 20 per cent of our students are streaking away from the average, and the bottom 20 per cent, or 25 or 30 per cent—whatever it is—are being abandoned. This is a significant problem and it will not go away. No matter how many times the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) denies it, it is a problem that has resource implications.

There is an increase in the alienation and the isolation of youth. Additional problems for young people seeking employment were often mentioned in the public hearings. Analysed further, they always meant lack of success, lack of confidence, lack of security and lack of love. This is a problem and it will not go away. It needs to be addressed when children are young and it is just as important as the literacy debate. At the extreme end of this alienation, insecurity and isolation is Australia's alarming youth suicide rate. This is this nation's shame. It also will not go away.

The actual resources allocated that directly go to the benefit of children are a national shame. Minister Kemp is correct to describe literacy at crisis levels in Australia, but he is completely wrong and, in fact, somewhat dishonest in refusing to acknowledge the resource implications. He and his Orwell‐like responses on education expenditure will, as certainly as night follows day, have their day of reckoning.

The second point I wish to raise concerns what I refer to as the training period of young people from 15 to 20 years of age. The report clearly found that career guidance for young people in secondary schools is almost non‐existent. The person chosen as the careers guidance officer was more often than not chosen by that famous method—the short straw method. Who in their right mind would volunteer for that position and be responsible for giving counselling to more than 1,000 students?

I have been in education for most of my life. It was always illuminating in a most ironic way that people in education described as bright were, in practical terms, not so bright, and often people who were described as not so bright, in practical terms got the best results. There is a lot of ego, a lot of snobbery and a lot of false praise.

The other main factor affecting careers guidance was the superficial, irregular and, at times, non‐existent relationship that existed between secondary schools, training providers—including TAFE and employers—and employer organisations. In that context, training and preparation and opportunity for entry level jobs are limited far more than they ought to be.

The third point I wish to make is aimed directly at state and federal governments of all persuasions in their failure to provide leadership and employment opportunities for young people. Public job creation is relatively efficient. It is socially productive, since it provides younger workers at that very crucial first entry level with much needed job experience. The federal and state public services, public works programs and state utilities in power and water, for example, can provide positions in traineeships, apprenticeships and entry level jobs.

As far as the employment of young people is concerned, government's record in this country in recent years is just appalling. It is in fact even lower than the record of the private sector, which in itself is also appallingly low. I wonder how many people in this House realise that the percentage of young people in public employment is 0.6 per cent. This is how we care for young people in this country and how we provide opportunities—0.6 per cent. It is a damned shame and a disgrace. The private sector percentage is 2.6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having them in public employment is not necessarily helping them. There is always the private sector.

—You did not listen to what I said. Public employment is very efficient and socially productive—and we should not forget that point. The implementation of policies for public job creation and private sector subsidies can be done fairly quickly, and if it is designed to avoid an unproductive substitution of subsidised for unsubsidised workers it can promote the much needed impetus our young people need with employment opportunities—that confidence, that security, that first step.

SPEECH.PARA: In the current climate, it needs to be understood that the jobs are simply not there. If governments refuse to provide the lead, why would the private sector? The private sector does not have the same responsibility for families and for workers that governments do. Why should they? But the federal government does have responsibilities, and if it fails to meet them it will suffer its fate at the hands of the wider electorate. Just look around the world at how national governments have been lasting one term; look at what happened in Portugal and in France.

TALK.START.PARA: —This government will last for—

—We will see. What about the future? In their book The Judas Economy , published this year, William Wolman and Anne Colamosca pointed out that people in the developed world earning their living from work are in a race without the finishing line. They live in an economy where their standard of living stagnates, where their job security is continually threatened and, since the end of the Cold War, where they have found no peace.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst corporate profitability has reached unprecedented levels, wage gains are meagre. Wolman and Colamosca point out that the triumph of capital has tilted the playing field against those who earn their living from work throughout the industrialised world. Blue‐collar workers copped it in the 1980s. White‐collar workers are copping it now in the 1990s, and it will not let up. Elite workers such as doctors, lawyers and accountants are next, and they will be forced to compete with the hundreds of thousands of graduates from the developing world who will be competing, at a fraction of the cost, with our own graduates, in an increasingly technological world and a global economy that ignores the boundaries of nation states.

Like a cyclone, capitalism is changing the political and economic structures of all countries, developed and developing. The market is now god. The market has no conscience whatsoever and economic planning is becoming the devil incarnate. Free market ideology has finally claimed a total victory.

TALK.START.PARA: —You sound like a socialist!

—It is not something to laugh about; this is a serious matter. Since capitalism first emerged in Holland, some 400 years ago, it has always been challenged. It is not being challenged now. Since the end of the Cold War, the market has run roughshod over ordinary citizens in the developed world and nowhere has that impact been felt greater than by our young people.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, I say the following. Firstly, as the Channel 9 campaign for jobs clearly demonstrated, the jobs are simply not there. Secondly, when it comes to expenditure on the five‐ to 15‐year‐old age group in Australia, we must appreciate and recognise that we have one of the lowest expenditures in the developed world and that particular fact will lead, and is leading, to dire consequences. Thirdly, when the 15‐ to 20‐year‐old training age group are considered, we learn in the inquiry report that the relationships between training providers, employers and schools—that trinity—ought to work closely together. What do we find? We find that it is nothing but superficial. There are splendid exceptions to that but, in the main, they are superficial.

We find that the guidance career officers chosen by the short straw method have totally unrealistic expectations of being responsible in some cases for up to 1,200 students. Could any of us imagine what it must be like to be that person in a secondary school and have that responsibility? It is just damned impossible.

Governments—all governments of all persuasions, both state and federal—are a very poor role model for entry level positions for young people, providing just 0.6 per cent of employees, whilst the private sector provides 2.6 per cent, an appallingly low figure as well, and not a good investment in our future and in our national interest.

Lastly, we should take cognisance of the future of work in a global economy with the market running supreme and roughshod over people's jobs, aspirations and security. We have seen blue‐collar workers cop it. We are now seeing white‐collar workers cop it. I do not think many of us realise that our elite workers and many of those ambitious young people who are in our universities—coming out as accountants, doctors, dentists and so on—are going to be competing with graduates from the developing world who will offer, through technological means, their labour at a fraction of the cost. Already, in Bangalore in India many of the financial services that are required in the United States are supplied nine hours ahead of time in India at a great loss of jobs in the United States. This will affect every country in the developed world and it is something that we should take cognisance of. I look forward to the government's response. I commend the report and its uncomfortable implications to this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brough, Mal, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training was very important and one that I was very pleased to be part of. It took us all over Australia, as I am sure has been mentioned before. Most importantly, it took us into the schools, something that has not happened as much as it should have in previous inquiries.

SPEECH.PARA: For the first time that I am aware of, young people in the school system were sat down in groups and we sat with them, asking questions and getting direct feedback from them—not from the teachers, the careers advisers or the peak bodies, but from the students themselves—about the challenges that they faced, about the problems that they had, and about the perceptions that they felt the job market had about them. That feedback raised some very interesting points.

I wish to talk today about the individuals that we met, the schooling system and the job market itself. I also wish to talk about something which has been left out of the report altogether, and that is the indigenous population, and about some of the evidence we heard from individuals dealing with that sector of the community.

Firstly, whenever you talk to any employer about youth employment or unemployment, one of the first things that comes up is attitudes. But what I found very interesting was that, when we talked to both employers and young people, there was an interesting mix of views about how they were perceived. It is very much determined by the business person's experience and their lack or otherwise of ability in dealing with the job market. I found that many business people show that they really do not have the skills, the knowledge, the time or the patience with which to work with any potential employee, let alone young employees.

There was quite often a stereotyping of young people as those who do not want to work and whom the world owes a living. And yes, there is certainly a percentage of that type, and we all acknowledge it. But there is also a large number of young people out there who really do want to work. The problem is whether they are being equipped for the job market. Quite simply put, in many areas of Australia they are not. The fact is that the first job I had was pumping petrol. You cannot pump petrol today as a job, because everybody does it themselves. And so many other entry‐level jobs, particularly in the banking sector, have disappeared altogether.

These were the sorts of jobs that got people their start. They may not have stayed in them very long, but they showed them their rights and responsibilities in the job market. With that work now having disappeared, they are finding out whether the school system has moved along with the job market to provide the students with the skills that they need to first enter the market.

To answer that question, in my own electorate of Longman we sat down with a number of students from Caboolture, Bribie Island, Tullawong, Morayfield and one of the private schools, St Columban's. We asked them about their expectations when it came to numeracy and literacy, and this was at a time when that was very much in the news. To be quite frank, the group that we were with were the higher echelons of the school. They were the better performers from all of these schools, and most of them had the expectation of going on to university. I thought that they would be quite affronted by the view that perhaps their numeracy and literacy skills were not up to scratch.

What absolutely astounded me was when the questions were put to this group, `How many of you would feel comfortable in front of an employer with writing an essay of 500 words or whatever else?' and `How do you believe your literacy would stack up?' the overwhelming majority of these good students felt uncomfortable with their level of skills. The sort of reply we heard was from one young man who was very good at calculus and one of the other higher maths, for which I cannot even think of the term right now. He said that he goes with his dad on the milk run and, when someone gives him a $50 note, he is embarrassed because he has to get his calculator out to give them change.

That really is where we are at. When people start in the workplace, 70 per cent do not go on to university: they start at a lower level, and they must have those basic skills. Have we neglected them? I certainly think that we have. As was mentioned previously by the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) it starts at primary school: it does not start in years 10, 11 and 12. We must build this up all the way through. I commend the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) for his approach to numeracy and literacy, but we do need to have resources there. It is absolutely critical that not only do we talk about the need but that resources are provided. And that is something that I intend to push very hard for, in whatever time I have in this place.

We then went on to talk about attitudes—the big bugbear, the one that we see on A Current Affair and on all of the other news‐making programs; I do not say that they `report' the news; they make the news, quite often. The fact is that those students get very annoyed with their own peers: the ones that sit and do nothing and give the rest of them a bad name, or the one that turns up for a job, only stays for half a day and brings his mates in. That makes it difficult for them.

It was no different for me when I was in the army in a green uniform in Townsville. If someone did something wrong, you were all seen as the same, because you were all easily branded as `the army'. It is the same for young people: it only needs one, two or half‐a‐dozen such people in any district, and that can debase the entire youth population. There are many young people doing fine jobs and getting on with their lives, but we have to start looking at how we can best assist them.

The third area of the individual concerns expectations and here is where the parents come in. It seems to me—and I keep relating back to my own experiences because I think that is one of the best ways to build on where you are—that in the army when I first joined, the best of the best went not to the officer training school but to the apprenticeship school at Balcombe. You had to be really the elite of Australia.

But what we find now is that young people are staying at school until year 12. They were going to the apprenticeship schools at 15 and 16; they now cannot go until 17 at the earliest. Their expectations, after having completed senior, move away from being an apprentice and into going on to university. Perhaps this is going to do something better for them and, in some cases, it will, but it is horses for courses.

We find apprenticeships are at a 30‐year low. There are a lot of reasons for that, but one is the expectation of the parents that if the young person stays on to year 12, the only chance they have is if they get a university degree and the young person has the same view. At Bribie Island—again, one of the schools in my electorate—it was reinforced by every student that the school pushed them into an academic line and that if you did not see a future for yourself in academia, then you really did not have a future. That is really quite damaging for any young person because only 30 per cent of our population will go to university. What happens to the other 70 per cent of those students?

The schools I refer to have a very good record and exceed that 30 per cent average quite considerably. They do a very good job, but we have to start to look at the expectations parents, workers and employers have for young people entering the market. What skill level do they have? What can they contribute to the business and what can the business give to them? Quite often, we found that the business people who were interviewed and gave evidence really had an unrealistic expectation of what young people could do for their businesses. It has to be a two‐way street.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I want quickly to speak about something that I first saw in the electorate of the member for Port Adelaide and that is a school with the skilled industry links program. I must say it dramatically changed my attitudes towards what can be achieved. They had a principal who could see that he had a low socioeconomic area with high unemployment and was very single-minded in how he was going to address it.

Startling results were achieved when he introduced a program where students went to work in a normal workplace one day a week and remained at school the other four days. In 1995 the school had I think it was 55 per cent of the senior class going on to higher education, training or a job and, one year later, 95 per cent achieved that. That is a remarkable turnaround because the job market did not improve.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peter Turner.

—Peter Turner is the man and he must be commended. We have started exactly the same thing in my own area and I want to give you an example of what it has done to the business community. We have involved people who had had very little to do with charitable organisations or the young, but who have been employers, with this skilled industry links program which has been funded by the federal government. Because of the attitude of the people on the ground, we have seen business working with these young people and the schools and in the very first week, young people have got traineeships.

SPEECH.PARA: They were young people who would have perhaps gone into their first job after finishing school and, not understanding their rights and responsibilities and what exactly a workplace is about, would have blown it. But the employer had no qualms about bringing these persons in. He was helping them and he realised that this young person had the right attitude.

I saw another example this week when one of the key people who is being involved in this did not have the young person in the scheme—the young person was working in another business—but he was so impressed with him that he put him on in his own business. It is starting to change their attitude because they are starting to work with the young people, rather than constantly looking at them as something to be despised. That is what we have got to work towards. I think that the federal and state governments have to put more time, energy and money into that sphere, as much as we do into further education.

One of the other areas of great concern to me was the way that young people expressed a great lack of knowledge of the TAFE system. The TAFE system was seen as being the third worst option. If you could not get into university and you could not get a job and all else failed, you went to TAFE. That simply is not the case. TAFE has to be sold better. It has to show people in the schools and the business community that if you have a diploma or you have a course under your belt from TAFE, it is worth its weight in gold. If we can do that, we can change the young persons' attitudes and open their minds up to different spheres which they can explore.

Traineeships and apprenticeships were not as equally poorly understood, but they certainly were not understood in the way they should be. When I finished school, people looked to go to apprenticeships. Today they seem like a third‐best or second‐best option. As was previously mentioned, we must have real career guidance. It is not good enough simply to say that, `If you do this course, you can do that at university.' We have to start to get down to the students and explain what options are available to them, what is going to best suit them, what is going to give them the best chance in life, and open their minds to TAFE, to apprenticeships, to traineeships, to university—the gamut of everything that is available—and not be selective.

If we can do that, we will go some way to filling the jobs that are there. As has rightly been pointed out, there are not enough jobs. I do not run away from that. This government and the previous government—and I am sure every other government—do in their own way what they feel is best to create more jobs for Australia. But the sad reality is that there are still many jobs there that are not being filled.

Just through the Queensland outback, in Roma we heard of apprenticeships and traineeships which could not be filled. At the inquiry was the first time I had heard that, and I must say I thought I had heard incorrectly—not being able to fill apprenticeships and traineeships just mind‐boggled me. We went on to Longreach where there is a pastoral college. We were told in evidence that each year they have 200‐plus jobs and yet they could only get 30 to 40 students there.

BREAK.PARA: This is not going to fill every job, but these jobs are going missing. Is it because it is so comfortable on the coast? Is it because it is such a harder lifestyle in the bush? Whatever the reasons, we must look at them and try and fill every job that is there. We were also told that over 1,000 chef apprenticeships have gone missing and Mount Isa Mines told us that they only filled half of their apprenticeships last year. Those things concern me greatly.

We must have some sort of database whereby the location of the jobs and the likely shortfalls in the future as technology changes are fed into the schooling system, TAFE and universities so we fill those positions. That is very important.

In the last couple of minutes that I have available to me, I want to touch on our indigenous population. As I said, this was not brought up in the report but we received evidence on it. In Mount Isa, the most disturbing thing that I heard was from a clergyman who is also a principal of a boarding school. He spoke about the term we often hear, `sit‐down money'. When asked to expand on this, he said, `We have young indigenous people that are at school. When they turn 16 and are eligible for unemployment benefits, their parents actually ask them to come out of the system to earn sit‐down money.'

We have to start to understand and appreciate the culture which surrounds indigenous Australians. The fact is that, if you are able to participate, particularly in these remote areas, in your cultural and ceremonial activities as part of the larger family group and put enough money or resources into that group to sustain it, then you have a lifestyle which is okay.

I am advocating that all Australians should be required to remain at school and, whilst they are at school, things such as family payments are only made if young people of all ethnic backgrounds attain a level of 85‐plus per cent in school. The first thing that we acknowledge is that young indigenous Australians are not completing year 12. We know for a fact that, if you do not complete year 12, the less chance you have of success.

We have to start looking more seriously at this incredibly difficult problem so that the indigenous population of Australia can enjoy as many as possible of the opportunities that this great nation has. It has been a great opportunity for me to participate in this inquiry. I recommend many of its recommendations to the government. I hope that all governments of all persuasions in the future will look to them seriously to address this most difficult problem of youth unemployment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the report, Youth employment: a working solution , can I say that the inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into issues relating to the employment of young people was very appropriate in view of the community's concerns about the high rate of youth unemployment. The issues looked at by the committee such as literacy and numeracy, vocational training, and school to work programs, have all been considered in previous reports to the government.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it was important for this current committee to revisit those issues. I also believe that the preparedness of committee members to give up valuable time in their electorates and travel to regional parts of Australia to listen to the views of young people, the community and employers, enabled the committee to produce a report based on the needs of all concerned. I was delighted that one of the school forums was held in my electorate of Greenway. I thank students from Blacktown Boys High, Blacktown Girls High, Evans High, John Paul II Senior High and Quakers Hill High for their participation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a good forum, too.

—Very good. It was at this forum that the point that the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) made relating to the shortage of career advisers certainly came through. At one of the schools it was said that there was only one career adviser for about 900 students, and I will refer to that issue later.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the committee's main focus should be on recommendations that enable the education system to provide to industry better qualified and more productive employees than is currently the case. We should remember that, due to the increased retention rates, young people are now leaving school at 17 and 18, where, say, 15 years ago, a large number were leaving school at 15 and 16, with the school certificate, and entering either an apprenticeship or a clerical occupation.

While some employers did express concern about the cost of employing young people, it was mainly in the terms of young people not having the skills and experience to perform the duties expected of them rather than the wages being too high. I believe the issue of wages and conditions should be left to the industrial parties. It is important that industry attracts high academic achievers into the trade areas by maintaining competitive wage rates. For these reasons, I strongly oppose a number of the committee's recommendations relating to industrial relations issues which reduce the income of young workers. There were, however, a number of the committee's recommendations that, if implemented, will improve the employability of young people.
I believe that Professor Sweet, from the Dusseldorf Skills Forum, correctly addressed the issue of the cost of training young people when he addressed the committee in June. He said:

One of the big costs that occurs in taking on an apprentice, which is often not recognised clearly enough, is not so much the cost of the wage or the on costs, it is the cost of supervision time in that first year of the apprenticeship.

Once they get over the hump of the first year, the supervision costs decline significantly. It seems to me a sensible way of addressing that issue is by ensuring one way or another that young people are made productive at the point when they hit the actual apprenticeship.

I think that is a good argument in favour of the sorts of vocational education courses in years 11 & 12 that link into apprenticeships and give kids the basic foundation skills that they need to work on site—occupational health and safety, quality standards, use of tools and so on—at the point when they hit the point of formal indentures.

While many schools are extending their school to work programs and vocational courses, the committee was of the view that improvement in these areas needed to be more comprehensive and broad ranging. The committee was advised that a number of schools had introduced a school to work program based on the TRAC model. Students in the TRAC program receive dual accreditation through the state education system, with the higher school certificate, and through industry bodies recognising the credentials that are received in training.

The TRAC program offers curriculum in four main industry areas—hospitality, retail, office and automotive. Students attend work placement with a minimum of four employers during their training. The work placement is highly valued and highly structured, and it forms a significant bridge between school and work. Supporters of the TRAC program claim that it is superior to school‐based vocational education because 70 per cent of the learning actually occurs in the workplace.

The committee was also made aware of the general shortage of qualified career advisers. Many people were working in this field with only school and university experience and little, if any, experience in the general industry. I suggest that schools make use of the more senior experienced workers who have been forced out of the work force as career advisers.

To highlight this point I will refer to an article that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 26 November 1997 entitled `BHP workers to be trained as teachers.' This goes to the core of what I am suggesting here. It says:

More than 30 workers facing retrenchment from BHP's Newcastle plant will be trained as teachers and guaranteed a job under an agreement struck between the company, the Department of School Education and the University of Newcastle.
A memo of understanding was signed in Parliament yesterday to enrol 30 workers in a specially tailored program to retrain them as teachers in technology and applied sciences.
Further on it says:
The company said yesterday the retraining system would allow the employees to continue working at the plant while studying part‐time for either a diploma or bachelor of education.

A BHP worker, Mr Bruce McGrath, said his decision to retrain as a teacher had come after first recovering from the shock of the announcement in April and then following "heavy discussion" with his family.
"In the end I decided I did not want my skills to die and the best thing to do would be to pass them on to children though education," he said.
Mr Aquilina said NSW had a shortage of teachers in the fields of technology and applied science and could guarantee the workers a job when they graduated.

While not strictly referred to as career advisers, certainly there is great advantage in having experienced workers like those people being retrained and then coming into the school system. Hopefully, that might be something that will catch on over a period of time.
I will once again quote Professor Sweet, who I believe makes a great contribution in the field of vocational training. He said to the committee:

We change our approach to career education and guidance from one which says it all has to be on the shoulders of an expert career adviser in the school to one that says it has got to involve much more strongly local employers and the local community.

I would like to thank the chairman of the committee, the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), for his work in seeing that the committee had the resources to carry out its inquiry. I would also like to thank the secretariat for their support.

I see the document as an ongoing document. I will be referring to it and its recommendations and submissions in my future speeches in this parliament and in my electorate. To that extent, this is already happening. A number of members have already referred to aspects of the report in their submissions in the other chamber. In fact, I have referred to it myself.

In my submissions on legislation relating to the common youth allowance I probably drew on the point that the member for Longman (Mr Brough) was making. His point was that while there are clearly not enough jobs there, as the member for Port Adelaide has quite clearly said, on the other hand there are on many occasions jobs there that go unfilled due to a lack of matching.

In my submissions on the common youth allowance I said that one way of overcoming youth unemployment, or certainly of reducing it, is for governments to research skill requirements for the future and then to fully finance four‐year apprenticeships in those particular skills using federal government departments, state government departments, and appropriate private industry.

Again I support the remarks of the member for Port Adelaide who quite clearly pointed out that governments in particular, and now unfortunately to a lesser extent private industry, are simply not training our young people.
