In my submissions I quoted further from the youth employment report. I said, relating to skill shortages:

Despite this background of high unemployment and substantial structural changes in the labour market, Australia continues to experience significant and in some cases severe skill shortages in some industries and occupations.

Some submissions and presentations to the inquiry flagged prospective skill shortages in particular industries. The committee sought further information from industry associations about current and prospective skill shortages but did not obtain many responses.
What information is available, particularly on prospective shortages, does not cover a comprehensive range of occupational areas.
It is of concern to the committee that young people are not, in most cases, aware of the opportunities indicated by the available information.

The report itself goes on to refer to the fact that we were told there were some 4,000 skilled jobs Australia‐wide in the hotel industry that were unfilled and that there was an acute shortage of some 1,000 chefs Australia‐wide.

The report also found that there was a shortage of welders and other skills in rural areas of New South Wales, and that some employers told of difficulties in filling apprenticeships and traineeships in some rural and remote areas. That was the point the member for Longman was making. In the manufacturing industry, the MTIA has reported a wide range of skill shortages in occupations such as technicians and engineers, in several trades and for sales people with technical backgrounds. What the government should be doing—and they should accept some responsibility here—is taking some steps to match these skill shortages with our school leavers and potential school leavers.

I found the work on this report extremely interesting. I was very impressed, in our deliberations and in going around Australia, with the attitude of young people. In many cases they are misunderstood. In most cases they do have a great desire to work. The only thing that deters them from time to time is the lack of employment. However, I do hope that some of the committee's recommendations will contribute towards making more employment opportunities available to young people. I note that some people on the speakers list were not members of the committee, so I look forward in particular to their contributions because they will come at this from a different angle. I will leave my remarks at that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report Youth employment: a working solution . I do so with great pride, as other members of the House of Representatives Employment, Education and training Committee have, and as a member of the committee responsible for tabling the report.

SPEECH.PARA: When we enter parliament, whatever our political allegiance, we invariably do so with the expectation, with the belief and with the conviction, I imagine, that our very presence in parliament will make a difference, if not to our nation, at least to our electorate and those we represent. Some may say that this is naivety. I do not subscribe to such a proposition. My experience with, and the recommendations contained in, this report are proof of the excellent work which can be achieved in this House.

It has been widely acknowledged by all commentators that the greatest shame facing our generation is the plight of Australia's youth, be it in terms of youth homelessness, youth suicide or youth unemployment. The correlation between these three characteristics is indisputable. It is a collective shame affecting not only suburban Australia but also regional Australia. This report, particularly the majority report supported by all government members, makes recommendations which are part of the process to righting the wrongs affecting our young kids.

The aim of the inquiry appeared straightforward: to examine the factors which influence the employment of young people and to identify how their employment prospects could be improved. On the surface it was quite straightforward, although at times witnesses and members had to restrain themselves from delving into issues of youth unemployment and beyond.

Despite party allegiances, I am pleased to say that most members approached this inquiry without any of their own prejudices and ideological biases. In fact, by the end of our inquiry, our faith in our young people was affirmed. The great majority of kids out there want to work, despite the outrageous and flippant remark by the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson)—I imagine it was more a flippant than a serious remark; I give him credit for that—that kids only want to go back to bed in the morning. Kids out there really do want to work and they want to have a job.

I do acknowledge, as previous speakers have acknowledged, that, while there is a strong desire to work, the number of jobs present in Australia at the moment is certainly far from sufficient to cover the demands. Young people want to work and employers want to employ them but they want to employ them only if the conditions are right.

We found in submissions from the employers that they are looking for conditions such as young people having the right attitude to work, a willingness to work, a desire to learn, punctuality, honesty and appropriate personal behaviour and presentation. They are looking for high levels of literacy standards; they are looking for young people who have a basic knowledge, at least, of the world of work gained through effective schools to work transition programs. I note here, and I will talk a little more about, the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation and the jobs pathway program.

Employers are also looking for the disincentives to employ young people to be removed—namely, the unfair dismissal provisions, the need to pay adult wages and an exemption from superannuation and payroll tax. All of these matters are covered quite well in the report. Some of these measures are well within the scope of this government and, may I say, the opposition to embrace, but I know that the debate on unfair dismissal provisions, youth wage and exemption from payroll and superannuation will continue to be a political football as the lives of our kids are held in the balance.

Employers have consistently rated attitudinal qualities higher than skills themselves. A witness to the inquiry, Ms Kirsten Palmer, the Melbourne Region Director of Work Placement Inc., typified the comments by employers quite nicely by saying:

What employers are really saying they want is the attitude. What they are wanting is the preparedness to work more than lip‐service—being able to take personal responsibility . . . If the kid does not have the right attitude to start with, you cannot teach them anything about work sills.

So there is an acceptance by a number of employers that they are quite willing to actually do their part in providing the training, the skills development, required for the job. They are not necessarily looking to the schools to do that. If the schools do, of course it is a bonus, but as long as the schools prepare those young kids for the world of work they have more than an even break.

Part of that preparation is the issue of literacy. Much has been made about literacy in recent times. The importance of literacy is indisputable, and I am proud of the fact that a number of schools in my electorate of Deakin have embraced the need to increase the level of literacy among their students. I am pleased to see that the difficulties encountered by a very parochial and often defensive group of state ministers throughout the country are finally being worked out. They are finally coming to the realisation that a compromise on literacy benchmarks, as proposed by the recent study by ACER, is selling our young people's employment prospects short.

Literacy leads to greater self‐confidence, longer school retention rates and inevitably to higher employability. I congratulate in particular one school in my electorate, Tintern Girls Grammar School, for being a pathfinder in the area of literacy with its excellent work in lifting the level of literacy in its students. Recently, I was pleased to be able to host a visit by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Dr Kemp) at Tintern. May there be more schools like Tintern; I know they are certainly out there in the electorates of other honourable members. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs is certainly putting into practice the very measures dealing with literacy which we have proposed under recommendation 3.1.

One of the other interesting recommendations from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training has been the proposal for a national youth guarantee—I am not sure whether many other members have spoken about this today—whereby every young student is guaranteed education from primary school right through to year 12 in secondary school. I am sure it is a guarantee that will strike a resounding chord in the electorate; it is that `every Australian under 21 years of age who has not attained year 12 at school will be funded a place at a high school, TAFE or a recognised training provider to complete a year 12 education or its equivalent'.

I am always hesitant to be embracing guarantees of any kind. I would hate to see this guarantee go to the scrap heap of other more notable guarantees of our time, such as the infamous `No young person shall live in poverty'—that infamous, hollow rhetoric uttered by the former Labor Prime Minister Bob Hawke. Of course, that is the nature of guarantees—it is a black or white situation. However it is certainly a notable and worthwhile guarantee to be discussing and proposing.

I know that our recently introduced common youth allowance will help to facilitate this recommendation through financial incentives and by providing our young kids with the opportunity to invest in their own future, so that they do stay at school that little bit longer and they do take the opportunity to embrace training and skills development for their own employability.

One of the notable discrepancies that this committee encountered in its inquiry is the value that is still attached to vocational education and training. I have spoken in this House on numerous occasions of the excellent work by this government to reinvigorate vocational education and training from its deplorable run‐down state.

BREAK.PARA: The previous government failed to recognise the value that the public still places on such things as apprenticeships and traineeships. Part of this educational process, of course, is having a strong work experience program. The Australian Student Training Foundation is one very notable organisation which runs excellent programs. It was a pleasure to be able to go to places like Salisbury High School—a school in South Australia well known by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford)—and see the excellent partnership that has been developed between school, industry, industry groups and the foundation itself. Their efforts and success should be a model for other schools in this country. That particular model is replicated a number of times throughout the country but it is nowhere near as prevalent as it should be.

As an employer of work experience students in my past life and now as an MP, I know work experience can be an excellent and rewarding experience for young people and for the employer, but too often the experience is a failure. The expectations of students of what they will learn and the lack of attention by the employers to the training requirements and their lack of willingness to make it a learning experience create a disappointing outcome. Young people should not just be seen as another pair of hands. The employer should not just be a recipient of some other employer's dedication and preparedness in helping young kids to make that transition from school to work. It would be fair to say that an element of altruism in business will never go astray and that every business should play a part in helping these young kids make the leap from school to work. Work experience is one part of that process.

I would like to refer specifically to two recommendations that were made by the committee. Recommendations 3.3 and 3.4 propose that the ASTF be given greater credence and support by this government and by the opposition. The committee recommended that the ASTF's criteria be promoted and be made a national standard for all workplace educational programs and that we should implement national guidelines, as far as practicable, for the assessment of workplace education programs. These are recommendations which I know, if embraced, will help these young kids to make that transition from school to work.

Part of a young person's preparation for the world of work is the knowledge of what to expect, how to search for work, the nature of various occupations and the attitudes required for work. These require strong and effective counselling. The honourable member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield) spoke on career guidance in his response to this report.

The committee found that the three important references that kids turn to for their career guidance are their peers, their family and their career teachers. Throughout the country we found deplorable career guidance situations. The member for Greenway and I travelled to two locations in Western Australia which particularly indicated the parlous state of career guidance.

The state of careers guidance really did vary dramatically across the nation. It is fair to say that the greatest critics of the standards of careers education and guidance were in fact the students themselves. One student, in Carnarvon, as I recall, said to his careers teacher, `I think you'd better go and write your resume, Sir.' That was indicative of the contempt in which that careers teacher was held. I must say I was disappointed when, on the way out to the airport that same day, we heard that the careers guidance teacher, after making his appearance at the hearing, had gone off surfing. I am not sure exactly to what extent he is interested in the kids of that area.

I do not want to place the blame totally on careers teachers, because I believe that in a lot of cases they themselves have been put into their position with few resources. Often, not only do the students not know who is responsible for careers guidance, but also they may only get one or two hours for the whole year in which to learn the art of being able to get a job.

I would like to refer in particular in this regard to the comment by one of the careers teachers, as an example of the position in which they have been placed. Ms Debbie Ralston from Kambalda Senior High School said:

I have just finished university and this is my first year of teaching. I have been given the vocational education program for the Year 10s. I admit that I have no idea, so it is like one of the kids said: the blind leading the blind . . .

That was the position that that teacher was placed in, which was to the detriment not only of the teacher but also of the kids themselves. The committee found that poor career guidance is partly responsible for skill shortages in some parts of the country, as well as for young people not knowing the opportunities that exist in the skilled trades.

I would have liked to have spent more time on this debate, but I will take the opportunity elsewhere to talk about what great work careers guidance teachers are doing in my area, particularly with the jobs pathway program, which 29 local schools out of 76 schools across the nation will soon be embracing to help kids in a school transition program. I will talk more about that at some other stage. I would like to say in closing that it was a pleasure to be on this committee. I do congratulate all members of the committee and, in particular, the then chairman of the committee, the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), who is no longer the chairman of the committee, for the fine work in producing and tabling this report as well as organising the submissions we have heard. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not one of those on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, but I have certainly read the report Youth employment: a working solution with a great deal of interest, given the interest that I and all members, I am sure, have taken in the problems of youth unemployment in our own particular electorates.

SPEECH.PARA: The term of reference for this particular committee inquiry was the factors influencing the employment of young people. From listening to some of the speakers here this morning, I think that to some degree we are missing the point that, until we generate the sorts of jobs that can be taken up by young people, whether they be unskilled when they begin or university graduates, then we really are running around in some sort of circle.

The committee has no doubt that the great majority of young people want to work. Nor have I any doubt that the vast majority of young people want to work. Even those who come into my office seeking an explanation of the social security system say, `We'd give this away if there could be a job at the end of the day.' The fact is that full‐time jobs have fallen 59 per cent for teenagers over the past 15 years—a point which is made in this report. One of the weaknesses is that, until we can generate more jobs in this economy—and worldwide, for that matter—we are really whistling in the wind when we talk about there being jobs necessarily out there that people will not take up.

Recommendation 2.1 of this report asks that training be a component of labour market programs. One of the tragedies of this particular government's policy was the dismantling of some of those labour market programs—not all of them—so that there was a recirculation of young people, to a great degree. I always thought that, instead of 26 weeks, it should have been three years with two days per week of involvement in a long‐term project, so that there could be a sense of belonging to something—so that it was not a quick fix and a one hit for those people who were then put, disillusioned, back on the end of the queue.

But there were elements of that labour market program that addressed the particular needs of those without skills who, even with an extra couple of years of high school, were not the sort of material able to be taken up in the traineeship and apprenticeship programs—and I will get on to those in a moment, too. What we need to address is that vast number of people we have out there in the community who 20 years ago would have been working on the roads, or would have been the process workers, or who would have gone to the Edgells factory in Bathurst, or would have had unskilled work with councils or with a vast array of organisations. They are the sorts of people that we have to give meaningful long‐term occupation to if we are serious about addressing the social ramifications of that dramatic reduction in job opportunities.

The best available opportunity for these people at the moment is a work for the dole program without a training component. I noticed that in the committee's deliberations in Mount Isa there was a comment from Rodney Wilkinson, the managing director of Mount Isa Group Apprenticeship, who said that if work for the dole is structured training, and there are job outcomes for it, it will work. There probably will not be job outcomes, but there should be some structured training in this work for the dole program or it is really, in my mind, only window‐dressing.

As far as the traineeship and apprenticeship program goes, full marks to the government for its attention to this area and its willingness to create more opportunities for the young people. But I am getting the message from small business that it really finds that it is being asked to take on the vast responsibility for traineeships and apprenticeships. The cost of labour alone worries them. Workers compensation, for example, is one particular factor they are terrified of. They need dramatic reforms in that area because if they have got to pay out, they cop the premium in the long run. It is not the insurance company that is paying it; the employer pays it down the track. I have got a truck operator in Bathurst who has $650,000 from a very spurious workers compensation claim. Of course, his insurance company may pay out the block amount, but he cops it in his premium in the years ahead down the track.

Also, 15 per cent of the adult wage back in the 1970s was the apprenticeship rate. Now it is something like 40 per cent. Again, I am getting the message from people in the construction and building industry that we cannot afford the add‐ons to employing the young.

So there is some sense in recommendations 5.7 and 5.8 of this particular report that the government legislates to exempt young people under the age of 21 from compulsory sponsored superannuation, and that it abolishes payroll tax on employees under 21. It may be all right to sit here and say that superannuation for all is a great concept and we have got to get these young people preparing for their retirement, and so on, but let us get them into jobs first. If these are major impediments to employment, let us look seriously at those recommendations because I believe that they make a lot of short‐term sense, at least.

We have heard, too, about careers guidance. It is okay to say that we need better skilled careers guidance teachers, and that we need more of them. We need more resources in this area. You can lead children down a career path and explain what particular jobs there are and prepare them for job readiness, but unless we are generating the jobs out there, much of this effort is wasted. Again, it is okay to have them job ready, but we have got to have the jobs.

BREAK.PARA: Where have we lost those jobs? We have rail cutbacks in my area, the ADI downsizing, and the power industry now being downsized in preparation for privatisation. Where are these vast organisations getting traineeships or apprenticeships? They are getting them from the group apprenticeships schemes. For example, Pacific Power at Wallerawang used to have a huge training school for their apprentices. No more. If they need any apprentice, they get a part‐time one that is shared around the district in the group apprenticeship scheme. I think that there is a responsibility here for those organisations. Email, I suggest, is about the only one doing any serious training of young people in that particular area.

There is a university emphasis in our treatment of young people and in particular in the cultural and the peer pressure that is imposed on them by not only their peers but their parents. In the report here it says:
The employment and educational expectations of school leavers are heavily influenced by parents, teachers, peers and television.

Hear, hear! I would suggest, as the member for Longman (Mr Brough) said, that we need to make TAFE far more sexy. It needs to be sold better. It has got some marvellous facilities that have not been well sold. I think that we have to convince young people that TAFE is a way of skilling themselves fairly rapidly, and more flexibly I would suggest, than is the university system. I have a young fellow who has just finished the HSC. He is not quite sure what he wants to do but he is going to do a business course, he hopes, at Newcastle uni in the hope that there may be something down the track that suits. We have some fairly heavy, but not too heavy, discussions. You do not want to push people too hard. Perhaps I should be applying this pressure from parents to go the uni course, but I am not saying that at all. I see some great opportunities in the TAFE system locally but unfortunately the kids want to leave home, spread their wings and fly to the coast. That is part of the difficulty in keeping them there and saying, `Look, there are some very viable options in the local TAFE college that you should seriously look at.' Five years down the track they may say, `I wish I had.' I hope not.

Anyway, I noticed a newspaper editorial the other day saying the absence of positive proposals from our political leaders to foster investment in jobs is a scandal. I'll say it is. Labor seems to be suggesting that its new policy—and I think it is included in the tenor of the minority recommendations—will simply try to spread the existing amount of work among as many as possible while the coalition is still saying the economic fundamentals are in place so job creation is just down the track. It is not only just down the track. I think it is around the corner, through the tunnel, across the mountain and so far out of sight the young people who have not got the skills really are questioning what this system can deliver them. I am talking about those unskilled who should be picked up by those labour market programs specifically addressed to that particular problem.

Have I got any answers? It is all right to sit and criticise. I think the government should take a more active role in the economy by way of maintaining and not cutting public jobs and supporting projects for infrastructure jobs. It could come up trumps after the scrutiny of the Parkes export airport project or by spending money on the Great Western Highway which was identified in the roads report as one of huge economic significance, but a poor accident record. Let us get serious about infrastructure projects like that, getting more freight by regulation back onto rail so we can regenerate those jobs on the per‐way gangs for the gangers along the western line and in the railway towns. All over Australia, I would suggest, rail offers a feasible alternative for public jobs to maintain infrastructure. We can then bring the private operators in to use that infrastructure, but not charge them what New South Wales rail access does, which is a factor by five out of the ballpark as far as TNT is concerned. They should not be expected to pay for infrastructure. I think we can and that would generate public jobs too.

There is a bit more I wanted to say. Mobility is a problem for kids. Mount Isa, we heard, cannot fill up its apprenticeship quota. I do not think in the report I noticed any recommendation to this effect, but I think one should be there for a travel allowance system to be far more generous than it is now to get people to job opportunities. I have seen them not able to get from Rylstone to Mudgee to pick grapes because of the cost of the transport so we should be looking at that.
The report looks at the Aboriginal unemployment problem. Page 30 suggests just how little creativity we have in terms of working out this problem:
The educational disadvantage experienced by Aboriginal young people is a difficult problem to address.

That certainly is not saying anything at all. Dare I suggest that recognition of native title—not extinguishment, not compensation—and recognition of the right to negotiate and not to own, and the esteem and the underlying support for the culture that would deliver might be a way of unlocking this dilemma? While we are doing so, how about restoring the CDEP program to what it was? There was work for the dole there before it was ever invented. It was happily accepted as a very productive program in many of our remote Aboriginal communities.

In summary, we need to be generating jobs. We need to be not creating them, but generating them. I think that the government has a large role to play in this process through public expenditure. In the minute I have left I will read from a letter from Tudor Furniture in Sydney. Mr Benfield, the director, wrote to me that:

With Australian import tariffs decreasing and employment costs continually increasing, to simply survive, we may follow the path of many Australian manufacturers . . . lay off staff and source products off shore.
Our business currently employs 65 . . . By importing our products, we will eliminate all manufacturing and 1 clerical staff, replacing them with only 2 storemen . . .

This move will eliminate the major cost factors which are currently strangling our business, employer based taxes and liabilities. These are taxes, costs and liabilities which are applicable only to a labour intensive industry. i.e. Payroll Tax, Worker's Compensation, Redundancy Packages, Unfair Dismissal, Fringe Benefits Tax, Superannuation, as well as Annual Leave, Annual Leave Loading, Public Holidays, Long Service Leave, Sick Leave, Maternity Leave . . .

I do not agree with all of them being eliminated, but there is certainly plenty of room for thought there about how we can micro‐economically reform small business in giving them a fairer deal to generate jobs. There has to be a public part of it too. Public expenditure on public projects and public infrastructure is the short‐term key at least to generating more jobs, particularly for our young.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne, Chris, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In beginning my short speech, taking note of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training Standing Committee entitled Youth employment: a working solution , I say that I listened with keen interest to the speech of the member for Calare (Mr Andren). There is only one thing I would say to him: you do not successfully solve the unemployment problem by spending your way out of a crisis in unemployment. That is exactly how we got ourselves into the problem in the first place. While I know that he thinks long and hard about these issues, I would suggest that he thinks and perhaps reads some more about some of the reasons why the Australian economy went through the difficulties that it did in the 1980s and 1990s. One of the fundamental reasons was the debt levels that the federal government had racked up, both for the government and for the country. Public expenditure on infrastructure, while it has its place, is not the means by which you reduce youth unemployment. Perhaps that will be covered by other speakers in this debate as well.

SPEECH.PARA: I only wish to really cover the section of the report dealing with the youth wage. The youth wage was perhaps the most controversial and interesting aspect of the report. I am sure the member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel) intends to deal with that matter too in his contribution, as he was the progenitor of the minority dissenting report of the committee. I am sure that the youth wage will feature in his contribution.

Institutionalised youth unemployment will not be solved, as the Labor Party presently claims, by making cosmetic adjustments to impotent and antiquated job programs from the Keating era. The Labor Party boasted to all Australians that, after 13 years in government, they were on the precipice of full youth employment with their notorious tax and spend policies. Not only does the labour market policy of the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) trespass the boundaries of conventional wisdom, but also it fails miserably to account for the fundamental necessity to significantly reform this nation's approach to creating jobs for our youth.

The coalition government has long maintained that creating more jobs for our youth is not only a priority but an issue that must be approached with innovation, ingenuity and enterprise. In doing so, we—the people and the government—must challenge previously accepted norms and practices. Accordingly, the standing committee was prepared to demonstrate real leadership by challenging these accepted norms, thereby creating the opportunities for more jobs for our young people.

As a responsible committee, we examined many different strategies that have varying degrees of merit. One such strategy is the scheme which has become colloquially known as the youth wage. It is a significant development, which I believe deserves responsible and constructive debate in this committee. Presently, in Australia, there exist three broad categories of wage arrangements which apply to the employment of young people. Statistics indicate that junior wage rates apply to approximately 52 per cent of employees under the age of 21. A further 13 per cent of employees under the age of 21 receive a trainee wage rate. The distinction between a junior rate and a trainee rate is that for these purposes a trainee is defined as an employee who undertakes structured training as a component of the employment duties.

A third category comprises employees under the age of 21 who receive adult wage rates. Estimates suggest that this includes 35 per cent of the work force who are aged under 21. As parliamentarians, we must ask ourselves whether this situation lends itself to greater employment opportunities and work force participation for the majority of our youth. Under the current structure, there is some doubt as to whether this is presently the case.

Rates of national youth unemployment have been unacceptably high for many years. The former Labor government's approach to this problem ignored realities and avoided the tough decisions that needed to be made. The words of Mr John Gilmour, a managing director of an Australian company, are instructive. He stated:
The wage structures for young people are too high, forcing us to demand greater productivity of them than their years and experience can provide.

Before extensively discussing the employment and financial issues related to this statement, I think it is equally important to consider the social issues which this statement raises. More specifically, I refer to the understandable and reasonable expectations of employers for optimum employee productivity and accomplishment which can often place unnecessary and distressing pressure on young employees to achieve a level of performance comparable to experienced employees who receive the same wage rate.

The coalition government is acutely aware of the pressures faced by young people; this government's announcement of an $18 million initiative to arrest the tragic increases in youth suicide is testimony to this. I do not believe that I am drawing too long a bow in suggesting that job related pressures do nothing to relieve the stress of young people. Whilst work related pressure is largely unavoidable in today's world, perhaps it could be alleviated for young people, to some degree, if unnecessary and avoidable pressures were removed.

What is far more clear, however, is the economic and youth employment rate impact of the introduction of a youth wage. There is a general consensus among employers that many young people graduate from a secondary school education without adequate work skills and abilities, including literacy and numeracy skills—problem areas which this government has identified as a priority for improvement. That is not to say that these are skills which are beyond any potential employee. However, it is obvious that an employer has certain requirements from their employees and would generally not sacrifice these requirements in order to make a minimal saving on their weekly wage bill.

There exists a large body of statistics and anecdotal evidence which indicates that the archaic practice of employing cheap labour to minimise business operating costs is often an exercise in false economy. Quite simply, employers are not discouraged from employing the best person available by the incremental cost or saving offered by a lower wage rate or the benefit of a government subsidy which appears to make the package attractive to the employer.

The hidden costs for an employer engaging the services of a trainee can be both considerable and deceptive. Training tuition fees, and related costs, associated compliance costs, in addition to a range of employment on‐costs, all contribute to increasing the real outlay in employing a trainee. It is little wonder that employers are reluctant to chance the odds with an inexperienced young person whose employment tenure will be comparable in costs to those associated with the employment of an adult at the appropriate rates. There certainly exists compelling evidence to suggest that research should be undertaken to examine the relationship between the changes in the level of wages for young people and employment levels. That is a recommendation that the committee made.

A survey conducted in 1990 by the Confederation of Australian Industry highlighted the significance and potential of appropriate wage rates for young people. Among the many conclusions of the survey was that employers are not predisposed to employ young people on the basis of the lower wage in isolation from other factors. Whilst young employees were often characterised as enthusiastic, employers frequently cited experience and productivity as the main considerations when assessing the suitability of a potential employee.

From the research conducted it was almost unquestionably clear that employers do not decide to employ a young person on the sole basis of a lower wage rate. The significance of the advantage of an employee on a lower wage rate is only realised when the candidate has an advanced level of skills or experience which places them on a par with potential employees on an adult wage rate.

The implementation of a government subsidy program was also widely dismissed as an effective measure to address national youth unemployment rates. This measure is merely a short‐term fix to the problem of youth unemployment. No amount of subsidies or government initiatives will persuade a prudent employer to engage the services of a potential candidate who they do not think will make a satisfactory addition to their business. Productivity is the critical issue.

The main concern for many employers is getting the appropriate person for the position in the long term and whether that person is going to perform to the standards that their business or interest requires to offset the higher supervision and training costs that come with employing the services of a young person. This is the fundamental concept of efficient resource utilisation and it is frequently the bottom line for successful business people.

Other strategies to alleviate youth unemployment lack the cohesive and cognitive reasoning of the youth wage. An often popular strategy is the competency based wages system. Under a competency based wages system, as young persons acquire measurable competencies their wages similarly increase. The Retail Council of Australia estimates that of the 280,000 juniors currently employed in the retail industry, approximately 200,000 will be replaced by adults under a competency based wages system.

By further illustration, McDonald's Australia Ltd, a company which is fondly regarded by the coalition and often used in its examples, and its franchises employ over 40,000 young people. The skills associated with these positions are very specific but also very easily learnt. Similarly, Coles Myer, a company which employs over 110,000 young people, supports a youth wage rate but questions the feasibility of a competency based wages system.

A competency based wages system also allows for the possibility of an unhealthy degree of subjectivity in assessing an employee's competency. The application of an established and administratively workable youth wage rate will remove this concern.

Furthermore, a competency based wages system fails to account for the fact that certain occupations are physical skill intensive. An equitable and satisfactory application of a competency based wages system would be so complex that it would not be administratively feasible for the small business person. It would be a disincentive to employ a young person without experience. Indeed, the word `disincentive' appears to be a key descriptive word in most reports into youth employment.

Another disincentive that exists under the current system is the access and availability of social security benefits that can often perpetuate an unemployment culture. A recent cover story by Ms Kerry‐Anne Walsh in the Bulletin magazine focused on this unemployment culture and the consequent recreational lifestyles of young people who are entrapped in that culture. Quite simply, the article suggested that the youth employment system inherited from the former Labor government excluded widespread participation. The system was inadequate, irrelevant and difficult to access.

This is a topic which tends generally to generate confused debate. Anecdotal evidence is often quoted to imply that many young people have turned to a life at the beach on the dole rather than participate in the work force. I am very reluctant to accept this suggestion. In my electorate of Sturt I have yet to see any evidence of young people preferring unemployment benefits to a job.

I submit that previously mentioned benefits of a youth wages system are far more meritorious than the `dole money is a disincentive to young people' argument. In any case, I believe that the present work for the dole scheme adequately complements the benefits of a more formalised youth wage structure.

BREAK.PARA: Whilst the present youth wage structure has enjoyed qualified success, there is some anxiety as to the unfolding legislative landscape for youth wages. The Workplace Relations Act 1996 has exempted junior wages from the anti‐age discrimination provisions until 22 June 2000. Further provisions of this legislation empower the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to extend exemptions on an individual case basis following 22 June 2000.

It is therefore critical that this government continues the reform process and restructures the existing framework for employment opportunities for young people. Fair and equitable wage rates for young people will reinvigorate the employment market and will give small business, the engine room of the Australian economy, the confidence to take a chance on employing young and enthusiastic people.

In conclusion, I congratulate the committee, which was mostly made of new members, from the class of 1996, on their report and on the interest that was quite obviously shown by the opposition in the conduct of the inquiry and in the report, evidenced by the comprehensive dissenting minority report which the opposition included as part of the overall report.

I would also like to thank the secretariat, who did a large part of the effort and the work in pulling the whole matter together and ensuring that we had a quality assessment of youth employment in Australia and of the reasons business people do, or do not, employ young people. The expertise in our secretariats is manifest for all to see. I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would agree that over your years in the House the secretariats of these committees have been of great assistance in fulfilling our requirements as members of parliament.

I would also like to congratulate the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) who chaired the committee in the conduct of this report and who has now been appointed chairman of the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts. I wish him well as the chairman of that committee. We will miss him on the employment committee, which he has been a member of for six years minimum; I think he was a member of the employment committee when he first came into the House, so it would be close to seven or eight years. I wish the committee well in the future and I look forward to working with the people who have established a good relationship over the conduct of this inquiry. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commence by also thanking and congratulating the secretariat on their fine work in supporting this inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training into factors influencing the employment of young people. It was a very long inquiry; unfortunately, the time that the committee had to consider the evidence at the end of the day was very brief and the time that committee members had to compose, discuss and, ultimately, determine recommendations and the content of the actual report was very limited. Nevertheless, the work of the secretariat was first class.

SPEECH.PARA: The most significant factor influencing the employment of young people, in my view and in the minority report's view, is jobs and the availability of jobs. Coalition members of the committee could not agree with this basic proposition, and that is one of the substantive reasons that compelled us to formulate a minority report. Even if all of the measures contained in the majority report were adopted and actually effected a significant change, at best what we would see is a change in the demographics of the unemployed, rather than a decrease in the number of the unemployed themselves.

BREAK.PARA: Under this government, youth unemployment has got worse, not better. This government was elected on a platform of fixing unemployment. They said, `Elect us and judge us on our performance in relation to employment.' What we have seen under this government is a worsening situation of unemployment. Essentially what this government has done is that it has gone on a deregulatory approach, thrown the issue over to the free market and expected that, having got what it regards as the economic fundamentals right, that will equate with growth and therefore somehow equate with employment growth. What we have seen is paper growth but not employment growth.

That is why Labor talks so much about industry policy—things like a steel plan, a TCF plan—and talks about having our hands on the levers to ensure that we are able to generate jobs growth and deliver the benefits for the community of economic growth. The community rightly expects, when it is promised a utopian future from economic growth, some return for all of the hype and the expectations which are raised from economic growth. What the community is not seeing is a return for all this economic growth that is supposed to deliver that utopian wonderland.

Within the majority report there are not concrete proposals to actually create jobs as such. There is a focus on increasing the competitive advantage of young people within the labour market itself, rather than on increasing the size of the labour market. Surely the focus of everyone's efforts must be on increasing the size of the labour market.

The majority report advocates, amongst other things, a highly questionable response to youth unemployment, focusing on youth wages and conditions. The youth unemployment rate has risen one full percentage point over the government's term from 26.8 per cent in February 1996 to 27.8 per cent at the time this report was written. That has been after fairly substantial, regressive reforms to industrial relations, so the supposed benefits of deregulating the labour market have not delivered employment growth—quite the contrary.

My electorate of Fraser has one of the highest youth unemployment rates in the country. Late last year it hit 50 per cent and has fluctuated thereabouts for quite some time. But clearly, it is an utterly unacceptable unemployment rate, and I regularly see the consequences of it upon young people themselves.

I will turn briefly to some of the proposals of the majority report. One is to abolish superannuation for young people. This is a proposition which is predicated on the assumption that costs of youth employment are prohibiting or discouraging employers to take on young people. But there has been no real attempt at all by coalition members to cost the consequence of abolishing superannuation for young people, on young people themselves or on retirement incomes at the end of the track. That problem is essentially left for future governments to deal with.

There is a proposal to discount apprentice incomes for time spent in training. It is a double‐dip discount that is being advocated. Apprentice incomes are already discounted, partly in recognition for time spent in training and for all the various on‐costs and hidden costs that coalition members have talked about. They are already discounted, and they provide an extremely low level of income for young workers, but there has not been evidence, in my view, that compels a conclusion that says that the decline in apprenticeships has been caused by apprentice incomes.

What we have seen is a fundamental change in what constitutes our economy, and those industries that traditionally engage apprentices have not grown at the same pace as newer industries that do not have a tradition of apprenticeship. Because of that, we have seen a change in the constitution of youth employment and a proportional reduction of apprentices, but that has not been because of apprentice incomes. The proposal by coalition members to effectively reduce apprentice incomes is, in my view, extremely regressive and does not acknowledge some of the underlying reasons for the proportional decline in the number of apprenticeships.

There has been some argument about a decline in the quality of apprentices that some employers—not all—have detected. Some employers say that they are quite happy with the quality of apprentices. Certainly, in my view there is evidence to suggest that the quality of apprentices these days is higher than it was in the past. You cannot argue, for example, that people being indentured are less educated now than they were 13 years ago; they are certainly better educated now than they were 13 years ago. The decline in apprenticeships can be sheeted home pretty much to changes in the economy rather than to a scapegoating proposition that says that it is young people themselves who are to blame and that the reason why employers are not engaging apprentices is that they cannot find good apprentices.

There is also a proposal that the previous speaker, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne), talked about removing protections that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission provides to youth wages. It is essentially a proposition that, in effect, freezes junior rates, because it is advocating that the rate be set by the parliament, effectively, rather than by the commission. Of course, the commission has to consider equity issues and fairness issues along with employment issues and the relative capacity of young people within the labour market to compete—the positive and negative things that they bring to the market.

Essentially, the coalition's proposal takes out of the equation those equity and fairness issues and fails in the majority report to examine the consequence of that proposition. It also fails, quite critically, to advocate a quantum of what that new junior rate would be. There is a great fear in my mind that what we are seeing here is a resurgence of propositions, advocated in Fightback, to do with junior rates. The coalition members do not say that they are proposing $2.50 per hour or $10 per hour. They do not say the actual rate that they are talking about, which is at the nub of the debate. They do talk a lot about their proposition or their assumption that the level of youth income prices young people out of the labour market. The evidence supporting that proposition is very scant indeed.

The statistical reality is that, in recent times, the comparative price of youth labour has decreased relative to adult labour and, at the same time, there has been an increase in youth unemployment. If the proposition is that wages substantially drive employment, you have a real problem in drawing the conclusion that youth incomes should be lowered, because, comparative to adult incomes, youth incomes have decreased, not increased, over time. But we have not seen a commensurate rise in youth unemployment, so the theory that is advocated by coalition members is not evidenced in reality.

Whilst there has been a substantial increase in part‐time employment in recent years, nearly all part‐time jobs are held by students, with 90 per cent of these jobs being casual. These jobs are not secure and are not seen as possible career paths. The increase in part‐time work has, therefore, not directly helped the problem of youth unemployment. Again this is one of the changes in the nature of employment in Australia. There has been an increase in casualisation and a decrease in full-time employment.

In August 1995, full‐time median weekly earnings for teenagers was $273 and $461 for young people from 20 to 24. A young person working 3½ days a week on this median full‐time wage is living on the poverty line for single people or $191.24 a week. We have got this great number of young people living essentially on the poverty line, and that fact has to be recognised when coalition members talk about lowering the income bar further.

A couple of colleagues and I sought, in the majority report, some discussion and recognition of the consequences of lowering youth incomes. There was discussion, for example, on the cost of overtime on employers and whether overtime should be knocked off for young people. That recommendation subsequently was not made by the majority, but there was a lot of focus on it. The general focus has been on reducing costs, but there has been scant recognition—no real recognition—of the consequences of reducing those costs on young people themselves. If we have got a large number of people living on the poverty line, my view is that we need to take that into account. It is extremely important. As of July 1997, over 60 per cent of workers between 15 and 19 years of age worked part time. So this is a very serious issue indeed.

The basis of much of the research into the impact of youth wages on youth unemployment is analysed in the minority report, and I do not want to go over it too much. Essentially, I could summarise my problem with the coalition members' proposal to lower the overall youth income level as the rejection of `a fair day's work for a fair day's pay'. I support the concept of competency based wages. One witness, for example, complained about doing the same work as an adult but being paid less for it.

There is an argument that young people are regarded by employers as involving more risk than older workers do and, consequently, that they should be a bit cheaper to engage, in order to reduce their comparative disadvantage in the labour market. That is inherently contemplated with a competency based wage system. If you have a young person who is not as competent as an older worker, you have, within that proposition, a system for rectifying the comparative disadvantage of young people in the labour market. But what we have instead is an age based discrimination that has not challenged or fundamentally rewritten the disadvantage that young people have within the labour market. A competency based wages system is a reasonable proposition.

The proposition of a national youth wage is, in my view, going to be a regressive proposition, having regard to the sorts of issues that are highlighted by coalition members in the majority report. As I have said, the impact of cutting youth incomes is quite dramatic. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the parliamentary Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and as a member for an electorate which inherited and suffers high youth unemployment levels, I would like to add my observations and comments following the release of the report, Youth employment: a working solution . However, before doing so, I would like to recognise the professional way all inquiries were conducted by the chairman, the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), and by the deputy chairman, the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), and also the assistance provided by the secretariat of Paul McMahon, James Rees and Gaye Milner.

SPEECH.PARA: Could I just remind the member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel) that the theory and rhetoric he has just gone on with do not put young people into jobs? He forgets it is the small businesses of Australia which are our major employers. Unemployment is still the number one issue facing not only our young people but society as a whole. Recent statistics released by Centrelink show that the youth unemployment rate in some parts of my electorate of Gilmore has dropped by 0.4 per cent last month and is still dropping, which is good news. But try telling that to the 26 per cent of young Australians who are still without work. The statistics are frightening and are an indictment of how we as a community, and our governments, have failed our young people over the years.

The statistics also have a face. They are now our children and grandchildren, nieces and nephews, relatives and friends. For the past decade, unemployment has no longer been considered as something which just happens to someone else. Many families throughout the Gilmore electorate are affected by youth unemployment. They are supporting a young person—if not necessarily financially, then most certainly emotionally. For the cost of unemployment is not only in monetary terms: young people who do not have a job lose a major way of networking in the community. They lose access to the normal interactions of a society which spends at least 40 hours per week—and, in many cases, more—in not only work situations but also social environments which have their own sets of rules and regulations and their own hierarchies.

In a society which places more than a monetary value on having a job, young unemployed people are the big losers in terms of low self‐esteem, low social skills and little or no self‐respect. While the doom and gloom picture must be acknowledged, it is much more important to address ways in which we as a community can improve young people's vision of their employment opportunities and therefore of their future. This is what we as the parliamentary standing committee have done, with this report. While much of the report and national attention focuses on youth experiences of employment, unemployment and training, one of the most important issues which must be acknowledged and addressed is the need to match the skills of the young person with the requirements of industry—the difficulty then being to define who matches these skills and whose responsibility it is. The report states:
It is clear to the committee that the expectations of young people and employers do not always match each other closely enough, and perceptions on both sides do not necessarily match the facts.

I can give you a very timely example of this. Last week, I hosted four of the brightest students from one of the high schools in my electorate of Gilmore. Having invited these four young people to Parliament House to give them a first‐hand view of the political process, not only have I admired the way they have handled themselves but I have also been interested to note the change in their attitudes in the four days that they have been here.

All of these students had an expectation of attending university to study, and prior to their arrival in Parliament House, several were considering a career in politics, while the others were looking more towards law and foreign affairs. During the week they sat at dinner with some of the members and senators to discuss a range of issues, including their future—more importantly, their perceptions of their future. Of note were their replies to questions about where they were going and what they were doing. Already there were second thoughts about certain tertiary courses which they had already applied for. Having spoken to several staff members throughout the House, these students were already considering a switch to broader education and skill requirements, rather than the traditional narrow lines of study such as were, and still are, presented as the primary options in schools.

These students are now looking not so much at a single degree, as at combining degrees, as well as some practical experience in the field of politics and further discussions with staff about working requirements. I believe that this is a prime example of where we are letting our young people down by not providing enough of a link between school and work to show them the real requirements of their chosen fields.

The same is true for the employers' perspective. The committee report noted several major concerns with regard to the requirements of the job and the skills of job applicants. It found that employers place paramount importance on attitude factors when making employment decisions. As a co‐director of a small business which employs some 30 people, I am well aware of the often frustrating experience of not being able to find suitable applicants for a position. Some have the right skills but the wrong attitude towards work. Others are willing to work but do not have the appropriate training and education. So where did we go wrong?
In a submission to the committee, a Melbourne based work placement company commented:

What employers are wanting is the preparedness to work rather than lip‐service . . . and being able to take personal responsibility . . . If the kid does not have the right attitude to start with . . . you cannot teach them anything about work skills!

Part of that attitude comes from their background and family which was a point highlighted in the report. Families these days need to recognise that those young people who do not go on to tertiary education, like the 70 per cent who do not, also need the encouragement and challenge of a career. However, these challenges can be limited, as the report has shown, if the required literacy, numeracy and basic skills have not been concentrated on. These, together with the building of expectations towards a job that may not be available in today's society, are without a doubt the responsibility of the school process, as is the lack of sufficient information being made available to the students on the availability and training requirements of the jobs of today, as opposed to those of yesteryear.

Today's business owners and operators look at what sort of role models young people aspire to and follow, especially in terms of family. According to a study by Flinders University students, many employers will employ on the basis of the recommendations of other workers who know someone who is available. The advocacy and information networks which are present in that form of labour market are very important in the matching process of a young person's skills and attitudes with the employer's requirements.

It was also clear in the inquiry that industry and business have a role to play. In fact, the report notes that few businesses, large or small, take on the role of getting into their community or schools to promote their industries or businesses and the job opportunities that they offer. This was particularly apparent in rural and remote areas where many of the young people interviewed could not tell the committee what job opportunities were available in the industries around their towns. So while employers were talking about the lack of interest in the jobs which were available, none of them had been to see their local high schools to talk to students about jobs in their industries.

This important process of matching young people with appropriate employment is very real. The jobs are there, as indicated in the recent jobs telethon—although I see in the newspapers recently that thousands of them have still to be taken up because, once again, the employer's requirements and the applicant's prospects were not matched appropriately.

It is often claimed that young people do not want to work. Yet the committee found that only one in 300 young people interviewed had a negative attitude towards work. I would at this point like to compliment those who were interviewed. I was impressed by their honesty, frankness and genuine interest in obtaining a job for themselves. It certainly gave me an opportunity to reflect on their comments and upon perceptions in the community of the young people who really do want to work but are unsure how to go about it simply because of a lack of knowledge or family support. This is supported by a recent survey by the Shoalhaven area consultative committee which shows that 70 per cent of all respondents would be willing to work for the dole.

Also, the Green Corps program, which I had the honour of opening recently at Bundanon, an arts icon in Nowra, was oversubscribed by young unemployed volunteers, too many for them to handle in one project. They have applied to conduct a second Green Corps project. These are young people who are volunteering to in effect work for the dole, while showing a genuine commitment to the environment and learning new skills and an appropriate attitude towards work.

The committee also found that there was a general failing by parents, schools and industry to adequately inform young people about the needs of employers and the realities of the youth labour market. I would like to focus on just one example of the clash of realities which was highlighted by the report. When a company first advertised for trainees to come in, they got nobody interested. Yet when they advertised for a manager of one of their shops, they all had these school students in year 12 applying for the manager's job, because it had a mobile phone and a car and they could wear a nice tie and a white shirt to work. But nobody wanted to come in and do the traineeship. Yet they all thought they were managerial material and no doubt some of them were. The realities of the employment market are not the same as the expectations of those applying.

Employers also have expectations and attitudes towards young employees. On a number of occasions the committee heard comments which indicated employers would not employ young people because of their perceptions of them. It is time that someone was open and transparent with them and explained that applying for a job with long hair, thongs and dirty clothes is not the way to instil confidence in a would‐be employer, be it male or female. It is also worth noting that employers showed no sex discrimination. They simply wanted someone who fitted their criteria.

In a recent survey the Bank of South Australia found that 57 per cent of people thought that young people required constant supervision. The burden, whether real or imagined, this places on an employer, in terms of perceived additional costs, is enough of a disincentive to employ young people.

I believe it is vital that young people are assisted to make a smooth transition from school to the work force, whether that be directly through training programs or through tertiary education. In Gilmore and the Illawarra region, the government has already allocated an extra $7 million for 2,800 apprenticeships and traineeships and $6.9 million for a Nowra campus of the University of Wollongong, 470 places for job placement for the unemployed and 270 places in work for the dole projects. Together with the Shoalhaven's own work for the dole program and Green Corps these show the commitment of this government.

Investment and initiatives for small businesses have also encouraged local industries to open their doors a little more to young people. But, at a Chamber of Commerce meeting recently in the Southern Highlands, I was again told that small business will not employ more staff until the new workplace relations laws are passed, in particular the laws which exempt small businesses from facing unfair dismissal claims within the first 12 months of employing staff. This was highlighted at every place the committee visited and must eventually be recognised by those opposite as being a real threat to future employment for both the youth and adult population. I cannot believe that the opposition is constantly opposing this initiative.

I believe the whole community has a role to play in improving the future employment prospects of young Australians. One important way we can do this is to stop talking down their future prosects and to stop saying, `There are no jobs for you out there, so don't bother.' There are jobs. We need to make sure the expectations of young people and their prospective employers are evenly matched.

It was also made quite clear that such issues as distance of travel, lack of transport and lack of suitable affordable accommodation for those prepared to move away from home to seek a job were a problem being experienced by the young people trying to find employment. These issues must be addressed by the whole community. We all have a role to play and I welcome the report by the committee as the base on which we can continue to provide job opportunities for young people.

In conclusion, may I also say how pleased both I and the electorate of Gilmore were in being able to host the visit by the committee to Nowra, thereby allowing them to witness first‐hand the strength, commitment and determination of our young people in the Shoalhaven. Their attitude showed that those who wanted to work can do and will do. All they need is an opportunity and a bit of guidance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This report entitled Youth employment: a working solution is one of the most important reports that has been delivered by this 38th parliament of Australia. It is a tribute to the former chairman, the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), whose constant and sustained efforts to improve what should be a culture of wealth and employment creation in this country are a model for us all. The report examines those things working for and against young people in the labour market, something not previously done with such rigour and sincerity, in order to find solutions by all members of the committee, whatever their political affiliations.

SPEECH.PARA: As young Australians leaving school have their hopeful optimism diminished to some extent by the knowledge that one in four will be unemployed for a period of time, it is well worth remembering the words of the British historian Kenneth Clark. After years of analysing the history of numerous cultures and societies in the BBC television series Civilisation, he concluded:
. . . it is a lack of confidence more than anything else that kills a civilisation. We can destroy ourselves by cynicism and disillusionment just as effectively as by bombs.

This report—and in particular the majority report—is founded on a dispassionate, non‐ideological view of what is required to assist young people in the labour market. It is a tribute to the commonsense of both the committee and its individual members, whatever their political backgrounds.

It also touches on one of the experiences that actually brought me into politics. On 2 June 1992, I addressed the National Press Club about the health and the human effects of unemployment. When I had finished, Ian Spicer, who was then the chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, was asked a question about the employment of young people. Spicer got up and gave a reply that was based on a survey that the chamber had just completed of the top 200 employers in Australia. Essentially, Spicer said that there needed to be a change to the way in which youth wages and working conditions were to be negotiated and that this had been identified almost universally by the top 200 employers as the major barrier to employment of young people.

Before he could even get his backside back on the chair, Bill Mansfield, who was then the vice‐president of the ACTU, jumped up and said, `Absolutely under no circumstances will the union movement of Australia ever talk to employers about anything like that.' I must say I said to the audience, `My goodness. Listen to this. Here are the people who create jobs, and who could and should employ more young people, saying this is the problem—whatever the merits of their solution.' Then we had the labour movement and those representing working people saying they were not even going to talk about it at a time when we had 34 per cent youth unemployment nationally, as we do now. We have up to 50 per cent youth unemployment in some sections of Australia—for example, Liverpool in New South Wales.

I said to one of my staff, as I left the Press Club that day, that it seemed so stark and obvious to me that the way we think and our attitudes and the way we go about trying to resolve our problems, particularly in terms of employment creation, have to change. Most young people want to work. Most young people are not bludgers. Most young people are not unemployed through choice. There have always been lazy people and there always will be. Some are young and some are old. But the vast majority do want to work.

Look at the figures published in the report. Full‐time and part‐time employment for 15‐ to 24‐year‐olds have dropped by three per cent since 1982. By comparison, in the same period of time, total full‐time employment has grown by 16.2 per cent, and total full‐time and part‐time employment has grown by 31.2 per cent. In other words, the job opportunities for young Australians have actually contracted in the last 15 years. In making that observation, I can assure you I am not passing critical judgment of governments in particular.

Let me address some of what I think are the most important recommendations of the report. The first is recommendation 3.1 that literacy and numeracy be taught in every primary school and be regularly tested and that there be resources committed to rectifying deficiencies in individual students. This is something that I think the parliament, both sides of the House, needs very much to support. I ran two small businesses, employing about 40 people—albeit, within the sheltered workshop of Medicare—for about five years. I was then privileged to be the head of an organisation with an $8 million budget employing considerably more people.

When people applied for a job, they would send their CVs and an application. No matter what the quality of what they were saying, if they could not spell basic words, and if the grammar was poor, you would discard that application and put it into another batch. I do not say that as an avaricious, self‐interested individual but rather as an employer who wanted people with some basic skills. We are doing a great disservice to young people if we do not ensure that this recommendation is adopted.

Tony Blair, the British Prime Minister, for whom Cheryl Kernot and most of us, I think, quite rightly have a very high regard, in his outstanding address to the Trade Union Congress in Britain on 9 September this year about the modernisation of Britain—I wish Mr Beazley could give a similar speech in Australia—made the observation that bringing kids up to meet minimum literacy and numeracy standards, or words to that effect, and continuing to offer a lousy education, is not in the interests of everybody and would not be tolerated by the British government. In a sense that is what our government is now saying here in Australia and I hope, in doing so, it is supported by the opposition.

BREAK.PARA: The other important issue that the report addresses is age based wages. The report acknowledges the lack of detailed research examining the relationships between changes in the level of wages and employment levels but coalition members—quite rightly in my opinion—recommended that the government make a submission to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission inquiry opposing the abolition of junior wages, as presently required under the sunset provisions of the Workplace Relations Act 1996. This recommendation goes to the very heart of the issue of unemployment, and youth unemployment in particular.

At the most recent public hearing of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration, with the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, I repeated the question that I had put to him six months earlier, that is, if growth is the solution to unemployment, why is it that after six years of continuous growth, we have 8½ per cent unemployment. On the most recent occasion, he was prepared to recognise that it is much more than the mantra of growth only, as promoted in recent years by the bank.

When we look at the growth we have had in the six‐year expansion since the recession we had to have in 1990‐91, the employment growth has been relatively weak. Compared with other developed countries, such as the United States and Britain, Australia has enjoyed similar per capita growth in GDP of about 3.7 per cent per year but our employment growth has averaged a miserable 1.7 per cent per annum.

If we look at New Zealand, which has had similar GDP growth to us, it has outstripped us with an average employment growth of 2.9 per cent. The US has enjoyed GDP growth of around 2.6 per cent per annum over the last six years but they have had employment growth of 1.5 per cent. In other words, our economy has been growing—I think all of us are pleased to see that we have averaged 3.7 per cent growth—but we are managing employment growth that is less than half our growth in GDP. Therefore, clearly, growth in itself is not the solution to the problem.

The issue for young people in particular is whether this is due to a more aggressive growth in labour productivity or because employers shed labour or avoid labour that they consider to be too expensive. The report recognises that we really need more research into the relationship between minimum wages, the price of labour and the employability of young people. In essence, our impressive growth rate has not given us as many jobs as comparable countries because real wages growth has been unrealistic for the excess capacity in the labour market.

The reason that this conclusion seems persuasive, at least to me, is that over the past six years, as I said, in which we sustained 1.7 per cent real wages growth, the US experienced 0.9 per cent real wages growth and the New Zealanders have had none. The other point, coming back to Tony Blair's speech to the Trade Union Congress, is that the unions need to be as concerned about the people who do not have work as those who do.

I surveyed my electorate last April and I will do it again in April next year, and the number one issue of concern to people was unemployment. If you ask Australians what they are most concerned about, unemployment will be right up the top. However, what actually happens is that on polling day most people say to themselves, `I've got a job. I don't think I am going to lose it,' and they will vote on other issues. A significant minority will vote on the basis of unemployment. I have a feeling that most Australians at the moment would rather live with 8½ per cent unemployment rather than pay the social and the economic costs that are necessary to make some real inroads into it.

The winter edition of the Reserve Bank's economic round‐up sought to quantify the two effects of GDP growth and wages growth on employment. The first effect was that a one percentage point increase in non‐farm GDP in the current quarter will increase employment by 0.8 per cent after five quarters. The second effect was that a one percentage point increase in real wages in the current quarter will reduce employment by about 0.3 per cent after five quarters, most of the decrease coming in the first two quarters.
