So, whilst on the one hand you have growth increasing employment and opportunities for young people, on the other hand every time we increase real wages by one percentage point we are reducing employment by 0.3 per cent. That is something that everybody concerned for the employment of young people needs to think long and hard about whether it is governments, whether it is the Industrial Relations Commission, whether it is unions who are doing their best to represent working people, or whether it is parents who are just simply worried about whether their kids are going to have a job.

Several years ago the Secretary to the Treasury, Ted Evans, said that unemployment was a policy of choice, and it is a sentiment I see recently reiterated by Professor Ross Garnaut from the ANU. I again ask myself the questions: are we serious? Are we prepared to pay the social and the economic price that is necessary to reduce unemployment and to create employment opportunities for young people?

I am very privileged at the moment because I represent the most affluent electorate in the country, but as I discovered when I was president of the AMA, if you want to change the world you need people with influence behind you. I was equally privileged for almost eight years to work in the second poorest part of Australia, a public housing estate where there were three generations of welfare dependency, 13 per cent employment, and where people really had lost hope. They felt they had been cut off from the economic mainstream of Australia.

If we are really serious about unemployment, as they have been in Britain and as they have been in the United States, we need to have a serious debate in Australia about issues that are politically unpopular. We have to look at minimum wages and their relationship to the social security system. We have to look at the relationship of our taxation system to the labour market. There has to be a serious examination of the impact of wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and capital gains tax on employability. We have to look at negative income taxes for low income people.

We have to look at the relationship between public housing, where people live, and the employment market. As an example, most of the people in Bridgewater and Gagebrook and that satellite public housing estate in outer northern Hobart, where I spent a lot of my time working, will find it four times harder to get a job than somebody living in Glenorchy in the outer suburbs of Hobart.

We must look at the relationship of the social security system and the safety net that we provide to low income people and its impact on the labour market. We must look at the interaction between schools, the education system, and the labour market. We must look at the impact of technology, the industrial relations system and labour market flexibility and dismissal provisions. We must look at state based regulations and the way they prevent employment from growing. Most importantly, we have to listen to employers about what is necessary to make them more inclined to take a risk, to acquire debt, to get out of bed, and to prefer to employ a person rather than take on another machine. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffin, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some brief comments with respect to the report Youth employment: a working solution . I was part of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training at the commencement of this inquiry, although I had moved on to other committees by the conclusion of the inquiry. On that basis I will not use my full time, but I would like to make a couple of points with respect to this matter at this time. I will focus particularly on some aspects of the minority recommendations and the report produced by some members of the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the issues which came up was labour market program funding. As I understand it, the view from the majority of the committee was that there was not a need for an expansion in that area, or certainly not for a restoration to previous levels. I would like to make a couple of comments on that issue in terms of how it impacts on the situation of young people.

There is often much debate about the question of labour market programs in terms of how they are seen and what is meant to be their actual operation and their worth. I think it misses a key point. The issue often with labour market programs—in some respects it is actually a misnaming—is the question of results in terms of jobs. As I know people who were involved in this inquiry are aware, attitudes and the conditions faced by young people are important considerations in determining their employability and their likely success in the employment market. The fact is that a lot of labour market programs that were in place in previous years, and that ought to be in place now, were aimed at that harder end of the scale.

When we talk about labour market programs it is not just that there is this thing called a labour market program. There should be a range of different programs that impact at different levels with respect to age, to experience and to the conditions faced by the people that they seek to serve. Programs that are designed to take into account those who have become long‐term unemployed and who are seriously at risk of never getting employment again—and often this can be a situation faced by young people—have to take into account those sorts of conditions.

The fact is that you cannot expect to have a strike rate in terms of employment for programs of that nature at 60, 70 or 80 per cent. Often you are talking about 20, 30 or 40 per cent—and, in some respects, so you should be, because the fact is that you could not expect to be that successful with people in those sorts of conditions. Often it is a process of moving people along to that area and that condition of employability.

The fact is that if people are in a situation where they have been out of employment for a long time or, in the case of unemployed youth, have never been in employment, there is a need to build up those skill levels. Those skill levels can be very basic; it can be the question merely, as has been mentioned by other speakers, of getting out of bed in the morning and being on time, of being in a situation where you actually see that there is a chance of employment and you can see that there is a way forward. This question of attitude that often impacts on people who are unemployed is about that situation of hopelessness that basically overwhelms them.

I know from my own experience when I was a bit younger—when I probably could have been classified as a youth, just—and was unemployed for some six months that I had great difficulty in focusing my own mind to a situation where I felt that I was still a worthwhile member of society and capable of contributing. For some months that was a real difficulty. That was after having completed a degree and still being in my early 20s, but in a situation where I did not feel there was a place for me—this was in the early 1980s—in employment.

BREAK.PARA: When we look at those sorts of programs we have to look at the question of that role that they play and the importance of that role in making younger people in particular employable. When we talk about labour market programs we have to understand the difference between different types of labour market programs, and the fact that they all play a role in getting people employable and in a situation where they can be out there competing in the marketplace.

Overwhelmingly the key issue, in my view, in youth unemployment is the issue which relates to overall unemployment—that is, the need for an economy to generate jobs and the circumstances that are there with respect to government policy on the role in which government can assist the private sector and facilitate, through its own funding, employment growth within an economy. I think there is much more that can be done in that area.

When we look at the question of the education sector there are also some issues there around the question of funding. The recent debate and changes on the question of fees et cetera in the tertiary education sector have implications here. Often when you are talking to young people the situation is that the hopelessness that exists in terms of their concerns about their likely employability also relates to the question of their education. What is very clear is that education, the generation of skills generally through a structured environment, is a key component in making young people—or any person, for that matter—employable.

The fact is that, as it appears to be becoming more difficult to be in a situation to gain those skills or more expensive to gain those skills, people will make choices. Often they will be making the wrong choice, but they will be making the choice on the basis of the world as they see it. And there are some issues there, too, in terms of ensuring that people make the best of their skills in terms of developing those skills with respect to actually going forth and becoming employable and therefore competing out there in the market. I will leave it at that for now because I was not scheduled to speak. I commend the report to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Mr Sinclair:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a report on a seminar on ANZUS after 45 years that was conducted by the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It was a two‐day seminar held in Parliament House on 11 and 12 August this year. I found the two days fascinating, not only because of the quality of the speakers—there was a whole range of speakers; it was opened by the then newly arrived United States ambassador, and there was a range of speakers there from the academic side, the diplomatic side and the political side—but because they put forward for me very much a historical context.

SPEECH.PARA: We so often talk about ANZUS—and we talk about it as part of our foreign policy—but it was interesting to listen to some of the speakers and to have them give their various points of view not only on the historical perspective of how the alliance came into being but also on periods when the alliance was under some degree of strain or under some degree of consideration.

BREAK.PARA: The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who drew on his experience as a former Minister for Defence, brought a perspective to it, as indeed did the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) from his perspective also as a former Minister for Defence at a period when the greatest strain came to that alliance because of the then Labour Party view in New Zealand about the banning of ships. They argued that whether or not they were nuclear powered they would not be admitted—and that put tremendous strains on the alliance. Indeed, it was very interesting to hear those two gentlemen's perspectives on it.

It is important that the parliament plays a role in bringing together groups like this for seminars. Another subject we debated in this chamber a couple of weeks ago on youth suicide was the result of a seminar which brought a whole lot of people to the parliament for discussions. I thought that this ANZUS treaty seminar, which brought together politicians, diplomats and academics to discuss issues, was also reflective. So often we respond to issues of immediacy—and a good example of that is the current currency crisis in Asia. We, as members of parliament, are expected to explain to our branch members exactly what is going on. Our families ask us and we have to give them an explanation. Indeed, sometimes the media even asks backbenchers to explain it, and we also have to explain it to our constituents.

When these things come up, they often catch us by surprise—suddenly this bank is collapsing or this security house is going under in Japan or some other economy is under great pressure. We have to make an immediate response as does the government of the day. This seminar was interesting because I was able to put it into an historical context and to understand better this element of our foreign affairs policy.

As is known, the treaty between Australia, New Zealand and the United States was signed by the representatives of its member states on 1 September 1991 and ratified on 29 April 1992. It is true—and this was a point that Des Ball and other people made during the seminar—that it has been a central pillar in Australia's national security policy over the last 45 years.

During that period, the United States has been Australia's most important ally—more important, one suspects, to Australia than to the United States. It is true also that the world in which we and the United States operate today is a very different world from what it was when this alliance first came into being. Just as the foundations that bought the alliance into being have changed, so have the conditions under which we exist today. Over the years, there have been tensions in the alliance, as I said before, not least the period when the nuclear powered ships did not visit New Zealand. Some people, during the seminar, suggested that the New Zealanders were perhaps not paying their way. New Zealand has always been in a very fortunate situation in some respects in regard to defence. It is a long way from anywhere and some people say that, to get to New Zealand, if there was going to be a conflict, you would have to come across Australia first. In many respects—

TALK.START.PARA: —But most of them are in Australia.

—That is true too. In many respects, New Zealand can afford the luxury of not making a significant contribution to a defence budget, knowing that other countries in the vicinity could protect her on the way. As I said, it was very interesting to hear the various speakers. ANZUS is still basically a defence treaty. Anything to do with defence has got to deal with a whole lot of other issues, including the environment and the economic situation. These issues have caused a very changing world.

BREAK.PARA: I gleaned out of those two days that the state of the alliance was good. It has stood the test of time and has provided a framework for cooperation in many areas. There are exchange visits, exchange assignments, ship visits and joint exercises. I particularly congratulate those who organised the seminar and those who participated in it. As I have said, it is very important that we have more of these seminars. Despite the generous words of the ambassador, I am not sure that the United States sees this treaty in the same light as Australia does. I am not sure that it is a cornerstone of United States foreign policy. Being the most powerful nation in the world, the United States has many important alliances—for instance, its relationship with Japan and China. To Australia though, it is important and it has been an important alliance. I think we have played our part well and there has always been a very bipartisan approach.

There have been some tensions within sections of the Labor Party about this, and I thought that that was dealt with quite well by some of the speakers. There has been a concern by some in the Labor Party—and there was a concern during the nuclear ships ban from New Zealand—that the Australian Labor Party should have taken a very similar line. I thought that Mr Beazley summed up very well on that. The point he was making was that the Australian Labor Party has never had a large constituency of pacifists in it. There may be individual pacifist members of the Labor Party, but he said that he did not have to deal with the same point that the New Zealand Labour Party did. I quote what he said during the seminar:

There has never been in the Australian Labor Party, at least since World War II, a serious pacifist strand. The argument in the Australian Labor Party has been between the supporters of the American alliances and the supporters of an armed and neutral stance.

So he did not have to face the same situation within the Labor Party in Australia that the leaders of the Labour Party in New Zealand had to face. I do not think there is a lot of difference between the parties on the ANZUS alliance. We both see it as very important to Australia and as very much part of our foreign policy, and it will remain there.

As I say, I congratulate all those involved in the ANZUS After 45 Years seminar. I thought it was an excellent two days. It brought great credit to the parliament and to those who organised it, and I hope that similar exercises are repeated in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The seminar to which the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has just referred, the ANZUS After 45 Years seminar was, I felt—as he did—really quite remarkable. I would like to echo the sentiments of the honourable member for Throsby and thank him for the remarks he made about me. To the others behind it, and to Senator David MacGibbon who is the chair of the relevant committee, I would particularly say, `Well done.'

SPEECH.PARA: I have tried to promote the idea of seminars as being a valid extension of committees and, in this committee and our four subcommittees, we have had some excellent seminars. Obviously, you have got to put them in balance, but part of their purpose, as I see it, is to bring the people from the wider community into contact with parliamentarians, to allow a dialogue not only between them and parliamentarians but also between often disparate parties, so that they can have some opportunity of meeting others in a different forum where they can actually give us some idea of how they see each other's perspective. As a result, we parliamentarians are seen as being far more relevant in the current debate. Certainly, in this seminar and in a number of others, that has worked extraordinarily successfully.

ANZUS is obviously a topic which has been a sleeper, if you like, in our defence and foreign policy issues for some years now. It is not something that many understand. It is not a subject which has necessarily a high profile in the debate within this place, although it is quietly there. Certainly, from my experience not only as a Minister for Defence but as a member for many years of the cabinet committee on foreign affairs and defence and on issues that pertain to intelligence, I would say that the relationship with the United States has been a very vital one in many ways, as many indirect as direct. The ANZUS seminar looked at where that relationship began—and really it was all post the middle of World War II—and at where we go from here.

Our relationship pre‐World War II was so subordinate to the United Kingdom and we were so much part of our relationship with the United Kingdom that America was on the sidelines. It was not until 1941 and the Curtin initiatives that Australia really developed a new relationship with the United States. I think that it is important in looking at this seminar that we pick some of that out, and I would like to do so in the few minutes that are available to me, and then look at where we go from here. There were a few very important issues that emerged from that that are very significant in determining where Australia's position is in the world today.

I was very glad that the honourable member for Throsby, Mr Hollis, referred to the situation in New Zealand. We have a funny relationship with New Zealand. I must admit that the longer I am in politics, the less I pretend to understand it—and perhaps I understand New Zealanders even less. The difficulty is that we are so similar and yet we are so unalike. There are so many areas where our relationship with the Kiwis is fundamental.

I am glad Larry Anthony, the member for Richmond, is in the House. Larry's father and I were very much involved in CER—Doug was far more involved in CER than I was. I was very much involved in its predecessor which was another NAFTA. When people talk about NAFTA today, of course they think of the North American Free Trade Association. But we had a New Zealand Australia free trade association which we called NAFTA before CER came into being and because each of us was in a different role at different times, New Zealanders were trying to fight Australian primary producers, particularly in Tasmania—and we do not have a Tasmanian in the House at the moment. But when we first started talking to the Kiwis, I had no idea that Tasmania and New Zealand saw themselves almost as enemies in everything they produced. They are very similar in characteristics because climatically they are akin to each other more than to anybody else, but we had hell's own job trying to persuade Tasmanian farmers that there was any point in getting into bed with New Zealand.

Yet, wearing another hat I have at the moment in this constitutional convention, we are in that extraordinary position where New Zealand is named in our constitution. If you look at the definitions, New Zealand is part of the Australian constitution. We need to remember that until 1898 it looked as if New Zealand would be a member of the Australian federation, and Western Australia would not. So in looking at the ANZUS relationships, which is what this seminar is about, we need to remember that time has moved on.

The Western Australians are occasionally here, but I am not always sure that they always want to be part of the federation either. But as far as New Zealand is concerned, it is not part of the federation. It has been part of ANZUS but it is not at the moment. We are part of the common defence relationship which is a counterpart to the common economic relationship. But from Australia's point of view we have always looked on the ANZAC tradition as being not peculiarly Australian, but including the New Zealanders.

When one goes, as I was fortunate to do only a month or so ago, to the Sinai to see the MFO there, the New Zealanders and the Australians have the same recreation area. It is the Annzac Cove recreation area—Australian Norwegian New Zealand. While I know that my colleague on the other side recalls some other instance that occurred that night, it is true that one forgets that that New Zealand Australian relationship at a personal level is always very competitive but very close. We take each other for granted and, as one who could probably speak a little bit out of turn, I would hope that New Zealand does become part of the Australian federation in some way for the future.

I know that my Labor colleagues will say that that will make sure that we will never have one central government, that New Zealand would never accept that it should be only government representing Australia and New Zealand, from my point even it does mean preserving the states—and I think that no longer since I became a centralist having seen the way Australia is governed—I think that there is reason for New Zealand to become part of our federation. It would overcome one of the problems which was identified in this seminar and that is the fact that New Zealand is no longer part of ANZUS.

I do not want to talk for long, but I wanted to say a few things, firstly, about the genesis of ANZUS. Those people who worry and wonder about what the Australian‐American relationship used to be, I thoroughly commend to you the paper by Dr Peter Edwards, `History of ANZUS agreement'. It is a fascinating read; it was an excellent presentation. He took us back to the world as it was at the end of World War II. I know that generations have moved on and people say, `That was yesterday.' But frankly, it is extraordinarily important that people understand that part of the strength of Australia as we move into the 21st century is that the relationship with the United States was developed in quite extraordinary circumstances during the second half of the 20th century.
I would like to put on record a few extracts from Peter Edwards's paper, because it is well worth remembering. First, Peter Edwards says of the ANZUS agreement:
There was nothing inevitable about it. ANZUS was created by a tiny group of politicians—
And it was tiny.
and officials in Canberra, Wellington and Washington against considerable resistance.
Everybody thought it was nonsense.

At the end of World War II, the United States was very much the victor. Japan was in ruins, Germany was in ruins—all Europe was in ruins. They had been fighting each other for 100 years and had only just managed to battle through. It was extraordinary that a little country like Australia and an even smaller country like New Zealand were able to persuade the Americans and particularly the American Congress to adopt an ANZUS treaty, which gave us, for all that they were a bit nebulous, the agreements to commit each to the support of the other in circumstances that have been very important in the subsequent 50 years.
Peter Edwards continues:

At the outset ANZUS did not have the almost unanimous support that it subsequently had—or appeared to have—amongst the relevant elites. I have referred to the United States military, but they were not the only ones who were uneasy. The Australian military leadership at this time was oriented far more towards London than towards Washington.
He continues a little later:

At the time of the negotiation of ANZUS, the British Labour government under Clement Attlee reluctantly accepted British exclusion. Shortly after its signing, Winston Churchill and the Conservatives returned to office and tried vigorously to reopen the issue. Churchill even accused Richard Casey—Casey, of all people—of being `an apostate to the Empire' for failing to support Britain's inclusion.

It really is quite extraordinary. Today, Britain has withdrawn from everywhere east of Suez. Britain's role in this part of the world is now largely represented by its continuing relationship with Pitcairn Island and I think there are about 30 or 40 people on Pitcairn Island. They have just returned to the South Pacific Commission, but that was because they suddenly realised withdrawal was not necessarily in their long‐term best interests.

I say all that with good heart, because I am a person who strongly supports British involvement in the five‐power defence arrangements and, hopefully, in an ongoing fraternal relationship with Australia but they are from another place. The point about that genesis and Peter Edwards's comments though was that he has spoken of the rather unique way in which ANZUS was formed. Another paper, which is included as an annex to the seminar report, was presented by Professor Desmond Ball of the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre of the ANU. It is appendix 6 of the report. I commend those who are interested in the subject to it and there are a couple of aspects of his conclusions that I think are very relevant.
Desmond Ball said:

The current transition in the Australia‐US security relationship is very complex, and in the context of enhanced multilateralism in South‐East Asia involves sensitive judgments, hard choices and careful balances. At the most general level, there is a need for a careful balance between the elements—
And that was the point I think is particularly significant:
of self‐reliance—
which we assert, but which frankly we are unable to implement—
the US alliance—

which is closer in military affairs than it is trade affairs where we are always fighting with Congress about the extent to which they have these all-American laws or the degree to which they want to apply extraterritorial jurisdiction, as a result of the passage of legislation in the United States. Continuing in Desmond Ball's words:
and other bilateral and multilateral security arrangements in Australia's national security policy.
There is this need for a very fine balance. He says a little later:
Balance and sensitivity are especially necessary with respect to Australia's efforts to commit the US to the region.

I think that is particularly relevant to the statement made by the Minister for Defence, Mr McLachlan, yesterday regarding Australia's strategic projection of the future and forward cooperation. It is also very relevant to the white paper produced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, with respect to Australia's defence policy in the region.

What we need to do is to have ongoing dialogue, not just talking across the chambers—whether the Main Committee or the main House—with respect to treaties of this character. We do need to involve outsiders. We need to look at the origins of these treaties and the way in which they evolve and recognise that, in the instance at least with ANZUS, we have been able to establish something that has incredible durability, that has given us quite phenomenal access in ways that would never otherwise be possible with the world's only superpower, and yet allows us to tell them when we disagree, where we disagree and why we disagree. That to me is a very important part of Australia being an independent sovereign power and one able to play a reasonable role in developing a more independent stance in our region.

As we go into the 21st century, it is important that we are self‐sufficient. It is important that we do not kowtow to anybody. But it is also important that we do it cooperatively, and not just with our great and powerful friends, but with our regional neighbours and with those who are further afield. It seems to me that being able to do so with those other countries gives us greater force and influence with the United States.

The United States is such an enormous country in its own right. People get myopic about their own concerns. One of the figures that has always stuck in my memory about the United States is that 10 per cent of the United States GDP represents 40 per cent of that of the rest of the world. That is really quite phenomenal. When you think of the size of the world trade and the world economy, 10 per cent of the United States economy represents 40 per cent of that of the rest of the world.

Our committee this morning had a fascinating briefing by the German ambassador to China about the growth of China. Of course, power balances change and new countries come into being. The significance for Australia is that we do have this ongoing relationship with the United States. It is not a subservient relationship; it is a meaningful one. It does require delicate balance in trying to assert our responsibilities as well as our rights. But this seminar did provide us with a very good understanding of where it was, how it began and where it is going. I would like to commend all those who participated and, in particular, thank those who came from so far to speak to us on that day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and the right honourable gentleman who preceded me, the member for New England (Mr Sinclair), I am very pleased to talk, albeit briefly, on this seminar. I regret that I was not able to attend this seminar personally. I want to take the opportunity to congratulate Mr Sinclair for the initiative in setting up these seminars. It is something that the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is trying in this parliament. I think it has been successful.

SPEECH.PARA: I chaired the inaugural seminar, which was into the Papua New Guinea relationship. I take the opportunity also to congratulate Senator David MacGibbon who chaired this one. Subsequently we had one on the role of the Commonwealth. I hope next year we will develop one on Cambodia. I think Cambodia is about to go through an interesting phase and it would be appropriate for us to have a seminar. There will be more on that, hopefully, in 1998.

It was appropriate also that this seminar be held in the 45th year of ANZUS. It is, as previous speakers have said, an alliance—and I emphasise alliance rather than treaty. It was very appropriate that we talk about it at this point, because it is fundamental to our strategic setting and—as the right honourable gentleman has indicated—something that was reflected and reinforced in yesterday's strategic policy statement by the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan).

It is interesting to see a couple of perspectives in terms of what this alliance is all about. I am going to take the opportunity to read into the record—I would like to read a lot more into the record because it was a very good seminar—some of the specific comments and, hopefully, people can digest them in due course. The first comment, in terms of perspectives, is from our own Prime Minister (Mr Howard) who, in an address in New York earlier this year, said:

Australia's close association with the United States has underpinned not only our security but also our stability, but most importantly it has given us the opportunity to share values across the Pacific, to share those fundamental beliefs of personal liberty, of individual effort, of a just society and a belief that it is appropriate always to aspire to the ideal of a better world.

I think it is important that we not only reinforce the bilateral or inadequate trilateral basis of this alliance but that we recognise that it has an impact in regional terms, quite beyond the bilateral relationship that exists between the United States and Australia in particular.
It was also interesting to read what the US Ambassador, Mrs Holmes, had to say at the seminar on the same subject. She said:

With ANZUS as a keystone, Australia and the United States have a mature relationship based on shared experience and shared expectations. It is rather like a good marriage. We have a deep affection for each other, we agree on almost everything, we are mutually supportive and we manage to work through the small differences.
Some of those differences have not been altogether small.
We have been through a lot during the life of ANZUS—Korea, Vietnam, some trade disputes—
and that, I suspect, is putting it mildly—
New Zealand's anti‐nuclear laws.
They were referred to by the member for Throsby. Mrs Holmes continued:

Together we have participated in the successful negotiations of the protocols of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, the Chemical Weapons Convention, the Nuclear non‐proliferation Treaty and the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.

She finished by saying that `the partnership works.' I agree with her, in general terms. Having lived in the United States for four or five years, I would say that if you make good friends around the world, and you make a good friend in the United States, that friend is closer, in my experience, than anybody else. I recognise the strong relationship that exists between our two countries at the social level as well.

It is difficult to pick out the better presentations given at the seminar but I thought what I would do, to emphasise the point I made at the opening about the emphasis on alliance rather than treaty, is quote from the presentation by Hugh White. Hugh White, as opposition members would know, has had a long relationship in the defence area. He is currently one of the deputy secretaries in the department. He is a good strategic thinker and he reinforced that in yesterday's announcement and statement by the Minister for Defence on strategic policy. At the seminar, he said:
The alliance is bigger and broader than the treaty, but I think the treaty itself is a very important part of the alliance, for reasons that I want to talk about in more detail in a little while.
He went on:

We have, since 1976, had Australian governments of all persuasions very closely focused on the primary responsibility of Australia to maintain the capabilities to defend our own territory without relying on the combat forces of other countries.
He further said:

Nonetheless, I think that even within a self‐reliant defence posture the fact that such a very powerful country has such a very clearly expressed obligation, with such clear connotation in the context of the treaty and the circumstance under which it was negotiated, that it would involve the use of armed force is a very significant strategic asset to Australia.
He went on:
It is worth noting that the wording of the treaty is interestingly broad; it is not just attack on our territory it is also attack on our forces in the Pacific area.

That emphasises the regional ramifications of this particular alliance, and not just the strict bilateral between Australia and the United States or the trilateral with New Zealand, and I think he has made that point well. He went on:
So it poses a very significant constraint in the straight military planning of anyone who intended to use armed force against Australia or our armed forces. And let me tell you,
as a working strategic policy maker, that is something that is very good to have in the toolbox.
The right honourable gentleman before me referred also to Professor Des Ball, who is well known to many in this place. He made some interesting comments too. He said:

Since the 1980s, the important aspects of the relationship from the Australian point of view have been the preferential access to US defence technology, which has been important in maintaining the high technology focus of Australian defence strategy . . .
That point was emphasised yesterday in the strategic policy statement by the Minister for Defence. Professor Ball continued by saying:

. . . the intelligence cooperation and exchange agreements and the access to the most senior strategic councils in Washington that derives from Australia's hosting of the important satellite early warning and signals intelligence ground stations at Nurrungar and Pine Gap.
He went on:
Australia has been at the forefront of the moves to enhance and institutionalise confidence—and security‐building measures—. . . and cooperative security activities in this region.
Australia has been one of the most active participants in the ARF.
Defence activities are at the very forefront of Australia's regional security policy.

That leads me on to the strategic policy document. I do not have time to read all of the section on the US alliance into the record but I want to read part of it into Hansard because it is worth reinforcing. It is an important element of this very important policy document. It said on page 18:

Our alliance with the United States is by any measure our most important strategic relationship. It is a major strategic asset and its preservation and development is amongst our highest strategic priorities. The alliance is a complex relationship which operates at many levels and in many ways, including annual Ministerial-level consultations.

First, and most fundamentally, it is a bilateral arrangement. That bilateral aspect involves a vast web of day‐to‐day bilateral cooperation in the maintenance and development of our military capabilities, including intelligence cooperation, access to some of the most advanced military technologies, and intense service‐to‐service contact through training, exercises and visits. This cooperation provides Australia's forces with technology and information which is fundamental to our defence capability. It will become more important in future as we become even more dependent on exploiting technology—
a point made very strongly in this document in terms of the technology edge—
especially information technology—to maximise our capabilities.

Moreover, it makes the commitment of US combat forces to our defence sufficiently likely to figure in the calculations of any would‐be aggressor. Nevertheless, we do not assume that such help would be provided. Indeed, such an assumption would be inconsistent with out self-reliant posture and our alliance obligations.

In one specific respect the alliance does provide a clear expectation of US support—that is, defence against nuclear attack. While the risk of nuclear attack on Australia remains very low, the possibility cannot entirely be ruled out. In those circumstances we would rely on the extended deterrence provided by the United States to deter such an attack.
This regional focus—
a point that I have also referred to earlier—

has always been part of the relationship. It is explicit in the ANZUS Treaty itself, which obliges each party to help the other in the event of either coming under attack in the Pacific area. But for both parties the regional aspect has become more significant in recent years—
I agree entirely with that point—

as the US‐Australia alliance has come to be seen by both sides as an important element in the post‐Cold War strategic architecture in the Asia‐Pacific region, helping to sustain US strategic engagement in the Western Pacific.
It finishes this particular section, on the alliance, by saying:

While the relationship is presently sound, we need to be active in managing the alliance and careful to avoid drift and complacency. The challenges in alliance management over the next few years will include sustaining our miliary capacity to operate with the United States by investing in necessary systems, and exploring new forms of practical cooperation—for example in the collaborative development of new systems and platforms.
As I said at the outset, this is a very, very important alliance. It is fundamental to our security in this region. It is fundamental to many dimensions of our society.

It is pleasing to note at the various levels, whether they be in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade or within the Department of Defence, that the relationship has been strengthened and enhanced under the present government. We have seen a number of measures, a lot of ministerial talks, carried out, both in the defence and the foreign affairs and trade areas and at the official level. It is pleasing to see the impact of those discussions in a wider regional sense, with officials proceeding to other countries in the Pacific rim, as a supplementation to this very important alliance.

It is pleasing to be able to talk to this record of the seminar proceedings. It was a very important seminar. I hope it will not be the last; I am sure it will not be the last. As I indicated in the main chamber last night, I get disappointed at times when some of these issues in strategic terms are not debated in this chamber or, indeed, in the other chamber to the depth that they should be. Giving the opportunity to members to debate this sort of report enhances that capacity. I commend the report of proceedings to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Anthony) adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether it is a common procedure for Departments to require job applicants to provide multiple copies of their application documents, even though there is no legal obligation to do this.
(2) Do some Departments require up to five copies of all documentation submitted by job applicants while others require three and some only one; if so why.
(3) Does imposing a requirement to produce multiple copies of complicated documentation when applying for each job pose a significant financial burden on some unemployed persons.
(4) Is the procedure being used as a de facto filter to rule out some candidates.
(5) Will the Minister take action to minimise and standardise the number of copies required to be submitted by job applicants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is common procedure for Departments to request job applicants to provide multiple copies of their application documents, however, if only one copy of an application is received, the applicant is not required to provide further copies.

(2) There is no legislative requirement for job applicants to provide multiple copies of their applications. I am not advised of any Department requiring up to five copies, however, it is common practice for Departments to request applications to be submitted in triplicate. This is for ease in processing applications and enables the efficient distribution of applications to the Selection Advisory Committee (usually comprising three members).

(3) There are a number of programs which offer self help facilities, which include the use of photocopiers to copy job applications. Job seekers who have been unemployed for 12 months or more, are in case management or less than 21 years of age can use SkillShare open access facilities which normally include newspapers, phones, photocopiers, PCs, facsimile machines and one‐to‐one assistance. Self help facilities are also available for applicants who are participating in job clubs. Job clubs are now part of the Job Seeker Preparation and Support Program—JPS. Post job club support for up to 13 weeks is provided to people who do not find employment during the program and this would normally include access to self help facilities, including the use of photocopiers. JPS, SkillShare and case management arrangements cease on 30 April 1998, however, a trial of self help facilities is planned to commence shortly, which will inform the process of establishing self help facilities at Centrelink outlets from 1 May 1998.
4) No.

(5) The Public Service and Merit Protection Commission's 1996 publication Recruitment and Selection, which provides guidelines to agencies on vacancy filling, explicitly states that there is no mandatory requirement to submit employment applications in triplicate. The publication notes that it is up to each department to specify in what form applicants may supply information, and that many departments now make use of electronic facilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the new arrangements for income testing residential care subsidies, which will commence on 1 March 1998, Government subsidies are reduced based on the additional income tested fee which the resident pays based on their income. QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 30 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that dental health is important in preventing other major health problems requiring expensive treatments which will otherwise fall upon the Commonwealth through Medicare for payment; if so, will the Government restore funding for dental treatment for the poorer sectors of society.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government acknowledges that dental health is important in its own right, though it is not a highly significant driver of other health costs as suggested by the question.

When coming into office the Government was faced with an unexpectedly large deficit inherited from the previous Government. In making its decision to cease supplementary funding to the States for public dental services, the Government noted that public dental care had traditionally been a State responsibility and that health card holders would continue to have access to public dental services, regardless of who funded them.
The Government is not considering reintroducing supplementary funding to States and Territories for this purpose.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Martyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 November 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Has (a) the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management, (b) the Plant Industries Committee or (c) subcommittees associated with either committee, sought expert advice on the potential risks associated with growing virus-resistant transgenic plants; if so (i) from whom and (ii) has the advice been used as the basis for public policy or draft legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the auspices of the Plant Industries Committee, there is a committee looking at good agricultural practices in the use genetically modified organisms (GMOs). This committee is developing policies for the sustainable management of plants that have been genetically modified using modern biotechnology techniques. As a part of this work, plants that have been modified to be virus-resistant will be considered. The Committee has not reported as yet.

The Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management at its meeting in August 1997 considered a report on gene technology regulation prepared by a working group of State and Commonwealth officials mainly from agriculture departments. That report made reference to virus-resistant plants in the context of the need to develop appropriate legislation to cover genetically modified organisms and product derivatives, but did not give advice on their efficacy or risk. The report was endorsed by SCARM and the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ).

In my press release of 8 August I said "The ARMCANZ meeting agreed on the urgent requirement for a responsive and coordinated national system to address the notification, assessment and approval of GMO activities and products.
"The system agreed on, in principle, today will be put to the Commonwealth and State governments for their early consideration.

"Such a framework must provide assurance to the community regarding the use of this technology, while ensuring reasonable certainty to investors and researchers to enable them to proceed with their activities under an effective, but not overbearing, regulatory arrangement."

On the 30 October 1997, the Hon John Moore, Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, the Hon Robert Hill, Minister for the Environment and myself announced that the Commonwealth Government had agreed that it was necessary to develop legislation for the appropriate regulation of gene technology.

Currently, expert advice of the nature referred to in the question is the responsibility of the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC). Over recent years GMAC has reviewed a number of applications for the release of virus-resistant plants.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 20 November 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the indigenous Land Fund set up to acquire land for Aboriginal persons who could not prove an association with their land.

(2) (a) Are resources being provided from the Indigenous Land Fund to Aboriginal persons who have lodged extant land claims; (b) if so, is this consistent with the objectives of and requirements of the Indigenous Land Fund.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The preamble to the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Act 1995 states that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund was established to help redress the dispossession of Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders. Section 191B of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 provides that the purposes of the Indigenous Land Corporation are to assist Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to acquire and to manage land so as to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders.
Neither the preamble nor the substantive legislative provision cited above make inability to "prove"

association with a particular area of land a qualification for land acquisition using monies sourced from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund. Indeed, the Indigenous Land Corporation's National Indigenous Land Strategy states (page 5) that, wherever possible, the Indigenous Land Corporation will aim to ensure that traditional owners (or people with traditional links to the land) become the holders of the relevant title. That Strategy was tabled in the House of Representatives in March 1997 as required by Section 191N(7) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989.

(2) (a) Yes. While the Indigenous Land Corporation's policy is flexible and decisions on individual proposals are made after assessment of those proposals against the criteria set down in the National Indigenous Land Strategy, the Corporation' s Strategy (page 5) states, as a general proposition, that "the ILC will give priority to land where a native title claim has not been lodged, and where it is unlikely that a native title claim would be successful. Consideration will also be given to other land fights mechanisms available to assist indigenous people to regain their land."

A successful native title claim may not, however, deliver to the successful claimants an interest approaching full, beneficial ownership of land (as, for example, in the case of pastoral leases, where a determination of native title fights and interests will be subject to the fights of the pastoral lessee). Their land needs will, in such cases, still need to be addressed and access to resources from the Aboriginal and Tortes Strait Islander Land Fund is a legitimate avenue for addressing those needs. Moreover, land of especial cultural significance to a particular group of claimants may not be claimable at common law or under the Native Title Act 1993 (because, for example, the land is freehold). Access to the Land Fund also provides these claimants with a legitimate avenue for addressing their land needs.
(b) Yes.
